{{distinguish|GLAAD}} {{Redirect|GLAD||Glad (disambiguation){{!}}Glad}} {{Infobox Organization |name = GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders |formation = 1978 <!--{{Start date and years ago|1978|MM|DD}}--> |type = |status = |purpose = [[LGBT social movements|LGBT rights]] |headquarters = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] (United States) |location = |coords = <!-- (Coordinates of location using a coordinates template) --> |region_served = [[New England]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glad.org/about/mission/|title=About GLAD - Mission Statement - GLAD: Equal Justice Under Law|publisher=}}</ref> |membership = |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{Url|http://www.glad.org}} |remarks = }}
'''GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders''' ('''GLAD''') is a non-profit legal rights organization in the United States. The organization works to end discrimination based on [[sexual orientation]], [[HIV]] status, and gender identity and expression. The organization primarily achieves this goal through litigation, advocacy, and education work in all areas of [[LGBT]] (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) rights and the rights of people living with HIV. In addition, GLAD operates a legal information line, GLAD Answers, where LGBTQ & HIV+ residents of New England can receive attorney referrals and information about their rights. The organization changed its name to GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders in February 2016.<ref>http://www.glad.org/current/post/the-generations-of-a-name</ref>
GLAD is based in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], and serves the [[New England]] area of [[Northeastern United States]].
==Background== GLAD was originally called the '''Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders'''. It was founded by John Ward in 1978, in response to a [[sting operation]] conducted by Boston police that resulted in the arrest of more than a hundred men in the men's rooms of the main building of the [[Boston Public Library]].<ref name=allis>{{cite news|last1=Allis|first1=Sam|title=Looking Back|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/404754947/|accessdate=August 2, 2014|work=Boston Globe|date=April 13, 2010}}</ref> GLAD filed its first case, ''Doe v. McNiff'', that same year and eventually all those arrested were either found not guilty or had the charges against them dismissed.<ref name=allis/> An early victory came in ''[[Fricke v. Lynch]]'' (1980), in which GLAD represented [[Aaron Fricke]], an 18-year-old student at [[Cumberland High School (Rhode Island)|Cumberland High School]] in Rhode Island, who won the right to bring a same-sex date to a high school dance<ref name="fricke_v_lynch"/>.
==Notable cases== * '''''[[Fricke v. Lynch]]''''': GLAD founder John Ward won a ruling from the U.S. District Court for Rhode Island on May 28, 1980, that the U.S. Constitution's guarantee of free speech prohibits a public school from denying a student the right to attend a school prom with a same-sex date.<ref name="fricke_v_lynch">{{cite news|last1=Karlan|first1=Sarah|title=In 1980, Two Boys Fought For The Right To Attend Prom Together|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/skarlan/in-1980-two-boys-fought-for-the-right-to-attend-prom-togethe#.mua0NngQ4|accessdate=April 23, 2015|work=BuzzFeed LGBT|date=May 30, 2013}}</ref> * '''''[[Hurley v. Irish-American Gay, Lesbian, & Bisexual Group of Boston|Hurley v. GLIB]]''''': GLAD founder John Ward became the first openly gay man to argue in front of the Supreme Court in defense of the rights of Irish-American Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual Group of Boston to march in South Boston's annual St. Patrick's Day parade. Massachusetts courts had affirmed that the group had the right to march.<ref>http://www.glad.org/about/history/hurley-v-glib</ref> In 1995, the U.S. Supreme Court reversed the decisions of the Massachusetts court, barring them from marching in the parade.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oyez.org/cases/1990-1999/1994/1994_94_749#argument|title=Hurley ''v.'' Irish-American Gay, Lesbian and Bisexual Group of Boston, Inc.|website=[[Oyez Project|Oyez]] |publisher=[[Illinois Institute of Technology]]'s [[Chicago-Kent College of Law]]}}</ref> * '''''[[Bragdon v. Abbott]]''''': In 1995, GLAD's case established that people with HIV and AIDS are protected by the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] (ADA). It was the first case that the U.S. Supreme Court had ever heard on the ADA, and the first involving HIV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/legal-docs/bragdon_us_19980625_decision-us-supreme-court|title=Decision from the U.S. Supreme Court|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gibeaut|first1=John|title=Filling a Need|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IT1o1lCOpfkC&pg=PA48&|accessdate=April 23, 2015|work=ABA Journal|date=July 1997}}</ref> * '''''Doe v. Yunits''''': In 2000, GLAD brought a case to the Massachusetts Superior Court on behalf of a transgender student, Katrina, who had been disciplined for wearing the clothing that matched her female identity. The Superior Court ruled that a middle school may not prohibit a transgender student from expressing her female gender identity. It was the first reported decision in a case brought by a transgender student.<ref>http://www.glad.org/about/history/doe-v-yunits</ref> * '''''O'Donnabhain v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue''''': On February 2, 2010, the U.S. Tax Court ruled that treatment for gender dysphoria qualifies as medical care under the Internal Revenue Code and is therefore tax deductible.<ref>In re Rhiannon O'Donnabhain http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/in-re-rhiannon-odonnabhain/odonnabhain-tax-court-decision-02-02-10.pdf</ref> * '''''[[Miller-Jenkins v. Miller-Jenkins]]''''' (2006).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glad.org/work/cases/miller-jenkins-v-miller-jenkins|title=Miller-Jenkins v. Miller-Jenkins - GLAD|publisher=}}</ref> * '''''[[Doe v. Regional School Unit 26]]''''' (2014): The [[Maine Supreme Judicial Court]] ruled that denying a transgender girl the use of a girls' restroom at her school violated her rights under the state's Human Rights Act. This case marked the first time that a state court ruled denying a transgender student access to the bathroom consistent with their gender identity is unlawful.<ref>{{cite news|work= The Advocate |title=Maine Trans Student Wins Landmark Discrimination Case |url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/transgender/2014/01/30/trans-student-maine-wins-landmark-discrimination-case }}</ref> * '''''[[DeBoer v. Snyder]]''''' (2015): GLAD's Civil Rights Project Director, [[Mary Bonauto]], argued in front of the U.S. Supreme Court on April 28, 2015, on behalf of same-sex couples seeking the right to marry. This case was consolidated with [[Obergefell v. Hodges]], and concluded in the landmark 5-4 Supreme Court decision guaranteeing a right to marriage.<ref>{{cite news|work=USA Today |title=Gay Marriage Pioneer Chosen to Argue Supreme Court Case |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/03/31/supreme-court-gay-marriage/70713840/ }}</ref>
==Work on marriage equality== In 1997, GLAD, along with Beth Robinson and Susan Murray filed a lawsuit, ''[[Baker v. Vermont]]'' on behalf of three [[Vermont]] couples seeking the right to marry. On December 20, 1999 The [[Vermont Supreme Court]] ruled that same-sex couples must be granted the same legal benefits, protections, and obligations as marriage under Vermont law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambdalegal.org/in-court/legal-docs/baker_vt_19991220_decision-vt-supreme-court|title=Decision from the Supreme Court of the State of Vermont|publisher=}}</ref> As a direct result of this decision in 2000 Vermont became the first state to allow same-sex couples to enter a legal relationship equal to marriage, known in Vermont as a civil union.<ref>http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/publications/vt-civil-unions.pdf</ref>
In 2003, GLAD received national attention for its work in winning [[same-sex marriage|marriage]] rights for same-sex couples in Massachusetts. In ''[[Goodridge v. Department of Public Health]]'', it successfully argued before the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] that to restrict marriage to heterosexual couples was a violation of the state constitution.<ref>Mary L. Bonauto, "''Goodridge'' in Context", in ''Harvard Civil Rights-Civil Liberties Law Review'', vol. 40, 1-69, [available online], accessed April 15, 2014</ref> In October 2008, GLAD won marriage rights for same-sex couples in Connecticut with a decision of the [[Supreme Court of Connecticut]] in ''[[Kerrigan v. Commissioner of Public Health]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=McFadden|first=Robert D.|title=Gay Marriage Is Ruled Legal in Connecticut|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/11/nyregion/11marriage.html|accessdate=April 15, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 10, 2008}}</ref>
On November 18, 2008, the fifth anniversary of ''Goodridge'', GLAD, working with other statewide groups, launched a project called the "Six by Twelve" campaign that aimed to bring same-sex marriage to all six New England states by 2012.<ref name="GLAD">[http://www.glad.org/current/news-detail/five-years-after-goodridge-glad-announces-6x12/ Five Years After Goodridge, GLAD Announces "6x12"], GLAD, November 18, 2008</ref> The campaign aimed to make New England a "marriage equality zone."<ref>[http://www.boston.com/news/local/vermont/articles/2009/03/24/same_sex_marriage_bills_gain_in_ne/ Same-sex marriage bills gain in N.E.], ''Boston Globe'', David Abel, March 24, 2009</ref> The campaign worked primarily through state legislatures and hoped to provide a road map for the rest of the country in 2012.<ref name="WT">[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jan/04/gay-marriage-backers-target-new-england/ Gay marriage backers target New England], Washington Times, January 4, 2009</ref> Within six months, same-sex marriage laws were passed in three more states, but the Maine law was repealed by the voters on November 3, 2009. After this decision by the voters, along with a coalition of other civil rights groups, GLAD proceeded with a two-year public education campaign in Maine. On June 30, 2011, [[EqualityMaine]] and GLAD announced plans to place a voter initiative in support of same-sex marriage on Maine's November 2012 ballot. The voter initiative passed, making Maine the first state to legalize same sex marriage through a ballot vote.<ref>''Wall Street Journal'': [https://www.wsj.com/articles/AP209adcacbac9485f900611a52972a05e "Gay marriage supporters plan referendum in Maine," June 30, 2011], accessed June 30, 2011</ref> On May 2, 2013 the "Six by Twelve" campaign came to a close when Rhode Island's legislature passed a bill allowing same-sex couples to marry and Governor [[Lincoln Chafee]] signed it into law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/marriage-equality/2013/05/02/rhode-island-gov-signs-marriage-equality-bill|title=Rhode Island Gov. Signs Marriage Equality Bill|date=2 May 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
When it filed ''[[Gill v. Office of Personnel Management]]'' in March 2009, GLAD became the first organization to file a [[United States district court|federal court]] challenge to Section 3 of the [[Defense of Marriage Act]] (DOMA) that prevented the federal government from recognizing the validity of same-sex marriages.<ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/03/us/03marriage.html |title=Suit Seeks to Force Government to Extend Benefits to Same-Sex Couples |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> On November 9, 2010, GLAD filed a second challenge to Section 3 with ''[[Pedersen v. Office of Personnel Management]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glad.org/work/cases/pedersen-v-opm|title=Pedersen et al. v. Office of Personnel Management et al. - GLAD|publisher=}}</ref> It won both cases in U.S. District Court and in the First and Second Circuit Courts of Appeals, respectively. In July and August 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed certiorari petitions in the U.S. Supreme Court in both those cases.<ref>http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/gill-v-office-of-personnel-management/08-02-2012-gill-v-opm-response-to-blag-cert-petition.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/pedersen-v-opm/pedersen-plaintiffs-cert-petition-08-21-12.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924022459/http://www.glad.org/uploads/docs/cases/pedersen-v-opm/pedersen-plaintiffs-cert-petition-08-21-12.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref> The Supreme Court chose instead to review ''[[Windsor v. United States]]''.
==Key personnel== * [[Mary Bonauto]] (1990-)<ref name="gladstaff">GLAD: http://www.glad.org/about/staff</ref> * Jennifer Levi (1998-)<ref name="gladstaff" /> * Ben Klein (1994-)<ref name="gladstaff" /> * Gary Buseck <ref name="gladstaff" />
==See also== {{Portal|LGBT}} * [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]] (GLAAD) * [[Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays]] (PFLAG) * [[LGBT rights in the United States]] * [[Mary Bonauto]], GLAD attorney * ''[[Hurley v. Irish-American Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual Group of Boston]]''

{{Primary sources|date=March 2010}} After consulting with [[scholar]]s and governmental experts, the Program on Humanitarian Policy and Conflict Research at [[Harvard University]] (HPCR) created in 2003 a multi-annual Project intended to restate the existing [[international law]]s applicable to [[Air warfare|air]] and missile warfare. This Project helped to formulate the ''HPCR Manual'' on International Law Applicable to Air and Missile Warfare. In 1923, the Rules of Air Warfare were drafted at [[the Hague]] by a Commission of Jurists. Since then, air power has become a crucial element of military arsenal and [[modern warfare]]. The developments in air and missile technology in the last few decades have completely altered [[military strategy]] and created distinct challenges to the protection of civilians in time of [[armed conflict]]. Although a number of international treaties have been adopted in response to modern warfare, including the four 1949 [[Geneva Conventions]] for the Protection of War Victims, the two Additional Protocols of 1977, and various conventions regarding [[cultural property]], [[biological weapon]]s, and [[chemical weapons]], many important aspects of air and missile operations are not included. Also, some of these instruments, especially AP/I, are not binding on all states, including the [[United States]]. Because of this, the Commentary on the HPCR Manual identifies US practices and positions which are consistent with the rules of AP/I.[http://www.ihlresearch.org/amw/about-project.php HPCR, ''About the Project'', 2009] ==About the Manual== The goal of the ''HPCR Manual'' is to give a methodical restatement of international law and air and missile warfare, based on the practice of States accepted as law and [[Treaty|treaties]] in force. Because the authors of the HPCR Manual have no [[legislative power]], there is no innovative aspect. By providing a reference on international law applicable to air and missile warfare, the HPCR Manual will help to stimulate discussions among legal advisors, military advisors, and humanitarian practitioners, which in turn will help improve the protection of [[civilian]]s in armed conflict. The HPCR Manual hopes to serve as a valuable resource for military forces while developing [[rules of engagement]], writing military manuals, preparing training courses, and the actual conduct of [[armed forces]] in combat operations, while also providing the armed services' [[lawyer]]s a cohesive text to assist them in their tasks. The HPCR Manual is a practical tool that will make decision-making easier in a real-time operational environment, while also giving confidence to those who utilize it. The objective of the HPCR Manual is to be of help to those who plan, approve or execute air or missile operations before rather than after the event. The HPCR Manual is also meant to be used by other segments of armed forces, such as commanders of forces that are receiving these attacks. Needless to say, it is hoped that the HPCR Manual will be used extensively in training and instruction courses in both [[war]]time and [[peacetime]], so as to familiarize prospective users with the patterns of behavior expected of them.[http://www.ihlresearch.org/amw/aboutmanual.php HPCR, ''About the Manual'', 2009] ===The Black-Letter Rules and the Accompanying Commentary=== The Black-Letter Rules of the ''HPCR Manual'' are a collective creation of the Group of Experts. The Black-Letter Rules reflect the [[consensus]] of the Group of Experts as to the state of the most significant elements of [[International humanitarian law|International Humanitarian Law]] bearing on air and missile warfare in 2009. Each Black-Letter Rule of the HPCR Manual includes a user-friendly explanation for both legal advisers and those who plan, approve or execute air or missile operations on both sides of the armed conflict. The commentary is done in "bullet point" style. ==Expert Participants== The Core Group of Experts is made up of 24 people, including Claude Bruderlein, Director of the Program on Humanitarian Policy and Conflict Research at Harvard University, Dr. [[Yoram Dinstein]], Senior Academic Advisor at HPCR and Professor Emeritus of International Law at [[Tel Aviv University]], Knut Dörmann, Head of the Legal Division at the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]], Dr. Frits Kalshoven, Professor Emeritus of International Law at [[Leiden University]], Colonel (ret.) W. Hays Parks, Former Special Assistant to the Judge Advocate General of the Army for Law of War Matters with the Office of General Counsel in the US Department of Defense, Professor [[Michael N Schmitt]], Dean and Professor of International Law at the George C. Marshall Center, and Dr. Zhu Wenqi, Professor of International Law at the Law School of [[Renmin University of China]]. Other experts, including 7 government experts and 6 experts that participated in some of the sessions, also contributed to the ''HPCR Manual''.[http://www.ihlresearch.org/amw/participants.php HPCR, ''Expert Participants'', 2009] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== (1) "IHL in Air and Missile Warfare" Homepage [http://www.ihlresearch.org/amw/index.php]
(2) "HPCR Manual on International Law Applicable to Air and Missile Warfare" [https://archive.is/20130415010359/http://www.ihlresearch.org/amw/manual/] [[Category:Laws of war]]

[[Devolution in the United Kingdom#England|English devolution]] |position = |international = |european = |europarl = |website = [http://www.aipmep.org Independence from Europe] |colorcode = #800080 }} '''Independence from Europe''' was a [[Minor political party#United Kingdom|minor]], [[Euroscepticism in the United Kingdom|Eurosceptic]] political party in the [[United Kingdom]]. The party was first registered in June 2012 but remained inactive until it was launched in October 2013 by sole party leader [[Mike Nattrass]], a disaffected member of the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP). It had no official political representation at the time of its dissolution in November 2017, but previously had one [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP) and three [[Councillor#United Kingdom|Councillors]], all of whom were once members of UKIP. Nattrass' deselection as a UKIP candidate in August 2013 saw him voluntarily leave the party and after deliberation, launch his own group whilst still an MEP. The party's name changed twice subsequently, largely due to the potential of voters mistaking it with UKIP; use of the word "Independence" in both parties' names proved particularly contentious, prompting two separate investigations by the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]]. Virtually all commentators dismissed the party as a means for disgruntled former UKIP members to confuse the electorate and split their previous party's support, an allegation Independence from Europe denied. This is despite the party costing UKIP between one and three seats at the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014 European Parliament election]], for which Nattrass' group is perhaps best known. Collecting 1.49% of the national vote, it proved to be their most successful election, although the party never had a candidate elected to any office. It shared a similar [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] policy platform with UKIP, with Nattrass stating as such amid the party's launch. Key policies included [[United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union|withdrawing the UK]] from the [[European Union]] (EU), prioritising relations with the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] and introducing more stringent measures on immigration. It further supported widespread use of [[Referendums in the United Kingdom|referenda]], promoting [[Devolution in the United Kingdom#England|English devolution]] and abolishing the [[National Assembly for Wales]]. Nattrass placed his party to the [[Left-wing politics|left]] of UKIP, however, due to both the party's general opposition to [[Privatization|privatisation]] and its proposed [[Nationalization|nationalisation]] of targeted infrastructure and amenities. == History == === Background and formation === [[File:Mike Nattrass.jpg|thumb|170px|Founder and sole party leader, [[Mike Nattrass]]]] Before establishing the party, [[Mike Nattrass]] had long been involved with [[Euroscepticism in the United Kingdom|Britain's Eurosceptic movement]]. In 1994, Nattrass joined the [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] [[New Britain Party]] and unsuccessfully stood for the group in the [[Dudley West by-election, 1994|Dudley West by-election]] of the same year. Alike most New Britain candidates, Nattrass was absorbed into and stood in [[Solihull (UK Parliament constituency)|Solihull]] for the single-issue [[Referendum Party]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]].Wells, Anthony {{cite web|url=http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/guide/west-midlands-european/ |title=UKPollingReport Election Guide 2010 » West Midlands European |publisher=YouGov |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qMvAbM6w?url=http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/guide/west-midlands-european/ |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} Led by [[James Goldsmith]], this party's policy was for a referendum to be held on the UK's relationship with the [[European Union]] (EU), specifically as to whether the British population wanted to be part of a federal Europe or a free-trade bloc without wider political functions.{{harvnb|Butler|Kavanagh|1997|p=71}} Nattrass subsequently joined the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP) and eventually rose to the positions of Party Chairman and Deputy Leader.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-23852962 |title=Mike Nattrass: West Midlands MEP 'failed' selection for UKIP |website=BBC News |date=27 August 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qMwebGJc?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-23852962 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} As the UKIP candidate, he was elected as a representative for the [[West Midlands (European Parliament constituency)|West Midlands constituency]] in the [[European Parliament election, 2004 (United Kingdom)|2004 European Parliament election]],{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/vote2004/euro_uk/html/37.stm |title=European Election: West Midlands Result |website=BBC News |date=14 June 2004 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNWXnAt9?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/vote2004/euro_uk/html/37.stm |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} and was re-elected [[European Parliament election, 2009 (United Kingdom)|in 2009]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/elections/euro/09/html/ukregion_37.stm |title=European Election 2009: West Midlands |website=BBC News |date=8 June 2009 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNWBQ4VF?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/elections/euro/09/html/ukregion_37.stm |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} Nattrass failed a candidacy assessment in August 2013 and was duly deselected as UKIP candidate for the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (United Kingdom)|2014 election]], prompting him to initiate unsuccessful legal action against the party.Walker, Jonathan {{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/ukip-mep-mike-nattrass-loses-5798307 |title=MEP loses selection battle to stand for UKIP |work=Birmingham Mail |date=29 August 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNYnoHuU?url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/local-news/ukip-mep-mike-nattrass-loses-5798307 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} He duly left UKIP and was in talks with the [[English Democrats]], but cancelled plans to ally with them after they prematurely announced his joining the party.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24354411 |title=Ex-UKIP man dismisses English Democrats 'deal' claim |website=BBC News |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNY4z944?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-24354411 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} Nattrass, still a [[Member of the European Parliament]] (MEP), instead launched his own party after considering a career as an [[Independent politician|independent]]. '''An Independence Party''''s creation was announced in October 2013,Edwards, Tom {{cite web|url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/NEWS/10773566.UKIP__in_meltdown__as_members_quit_to_launch_new_party/?ref=rss |title=UKIP 'in meltdown' as members quit to launch new party |work=Worcester News |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNb5IDPc?url=http://www.worcesternews.co.uk/NEWS/10773566.UKIP__in_meltdown__as_members_quit_to_launch_new_party/?ref=rss |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} being renamed '''An Independence from Europe''' on 7 March 2014 to avoid confusion with UKIP.{{cite web|url=http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/169499/4-attachments.pdf |title=Electoral Commission Records (An Independence Party) |publisher=Electoral Commission |pages=22–23 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNaQUM3J?url=http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/169499/4-attachments.pdf |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} Nattrass had previously considered the label '''4 A Referendum'''.Reid, Les {{cite web|url=http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/coventry-news/west-midlands-mep-mike-nattrass-6064413 |title=West Midlands MEP Mike Nattrass pulls out of joining English Democrats |work=Coventry Telegraph |date=19 September 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNZ9ffMf?url=http://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/coventry-news/west-midlands-mep-mike-nattrass-6064413 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] records show that he had registered his own party significantly earlier, on 20 June 2012. From this date, he had also been filing financial statements for the fledgling, albeit inactive, organisation.{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP1918 |title=View registration – The Electoral Commission |publisher=Electoral Commission |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820014059/http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP1918 |archivedate=20 August 2016 |df= }} The new party's development benefited from an incident in September 2013 when a [[Lincolnshire County Council]]lor, Chris Pain, was expelled from UKIP over an internal controversy. Fellow UKIP Councillors Alan Jesson and John Beaver supported Pain's innocence and were also expelled from the party for plotting to form a breakaway faction.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-24824856 |title=Expelled Lincolnshire councillor 'committed to UKIP' |website=BBC News |date=6 November 2013 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNd5RNVj?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lincolnshire-24824856 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} All three became members of Nattrass' party and proceeded to represent their [[Wards and electoral divisions of the United Kingdom|wards]] accordingly.{{cite web|url=http://lincolnshire.moderngov.co.uk/mgMemberIndex.aspx?bcr=1|title=Your Councillors|publisher=Lincolnshire County Council|accessdate=11 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150811044340/http://lincolnshire.moderngov.co.uk/mgMemberIndex.aspx?bcr=1|archivedate=11 August 2015|df=}} === European Parliament election and controversy === An Independence from Europe fielded 60 candidates in the 2014 European Parliament election, proposing representatives for each of England's nine constituencies.{{cite web|url=http://www.aipmep.org/Candidates/MEP_Candidates.php |title=MEP Candidates 2014 |publisher=Independence from Europe |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNrlDIbc?url=http://www.aipmep.org/Candidates/MEP_Candidates.php |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} The most notable of whom were Nattrass, who sought re-election in the West Midlands,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27127314 |title=Vote 2014: European election candidates for the West Midlands |website=BBC News |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNs7iPNz?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27127314 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} and [[Laurence Stassen]], a Dutch MEP who had recently left the [[Party for Freedom]] (PVV) and was vying for election in the [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]] region.{{cite web|url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2014/04/30/europese-verkiezingen-oud-pvver-laurence-stassen-1371772-a771897 |title=Oud-PVV'er Laurence Stassen kandidaat Britse partij |work=NRC Handelsblad |language=nl |date=30 April 2014 |accessdate=11 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qNsgE9uc?url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2014/04/30/europese-verkiezingen-oud-pvver-laurence-stassen-1371772-a771897 |archivedate=11 May 2017 |df= }} Stassen's unusual standing for the party "demonstrate[d] the extent to which MEPs whose true ambition is to remain in the [[European Parliament]] will go in order to remain in their seat"{{harvnb|Daniel|2015|p=47}} according to political scientist William T. Daniel. The party claimed to advocate a society comprising "[p]ersonal freedom with personal responsibility", supported by what it saw as "traditional commonsense policies". ===Constitutional and legislative policy=== [[File:Debating chamber, Y Senedd - geograph.org.uk - 1375999.jpg|thumb|left|The party favoured the abolition of the [[National Assembly for Wales]] ''(pictured)''.]] Independence from Europe's primary policy was to guarantee that the [[United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union|United Kingdom left]] the European Union (EU). This included its legal accessories, promising a withdrawal from the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] (ECHR). The party advocated the increased use of [[direct democracy]], namely through [[Referendum|referenda]]. Petitions with support from more than 5% of the electorate would trigger a national referendum on a respective issue, with the outcome legally binding by default.{{cite web|url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/ManifestoPolicies.php |title=Policies and Manifesto |publisher=Independence from Europe |accessdate=15 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qTnBPDGv?url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/ManifestoPolicies.php |archivedate=15 May 2017 |df= }} Conversely, Nattrass stated in 2014 that his party was adverse to the idea of a nationwide vote on the UK's membership of the EU, calling for "MPs with backbone"{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27412682 |title=Show backbone, An Independence From Europe party tells MPs |website=BBC News |date=14 May 2014 |accessdate=15 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qTsImBAo?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-27412682 |archivedate=15 May 2017 |df= }} to ensure a departure was delivered. The party advocated sweeping reforms of the UK's legislative process. These included a reduction of the number of [[Members of Parliament#United Kingdom|Members of Parliament]] (MPs) in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] by one third (650 to 430) and the replacement of the [[House of Lords]] with an elected upper chamber. Scheduled debates would have been introduced, upon which members for Northern Irish, Scottish and Welsh constituencies would return to their devolved legislatures, leaving the UK Parliament to discuss English affairs exclusively. The party repeatedly advocated the abolition of the [[National Assembly for Wales]], however, at one time adopting the tagline 'Abolish Assembly and leave European Union'; it suggested a referendum be held in Wales over the matter. Devolved legislatures' membership would have no longer consisted of politicians elected specifically to those chambers (i.e. [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (Northern Ireland)|MLAs]], [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSPs]] or [[Member of the National Assembly for Wales|AMs]]), but would have instead comprised those UK MPs returning routinely from the national parliament. On an individual basis, MPs would have been paid and claimed expenses in-line with existing British civil service guidelines. If elected, the party claimed it would "[b]uild a condominium to house MP's whilst they reside in London" and scrap their second home allowances. Legislators would have been accountable by way of an 'Independent Politicians Complaints Commission', with its members chosen by designated [[non-governmental organisations]] (NGOs). Furthermore, the activities of political parties would have faced greater regulation; [[Whip (politics)#United Kingdom|whips]] would have been removed from the [[Select committee (United Kingdom)|select committee]] appointment process and party sanctioning against rebellious MPs disallowed. ===Economic policy=== The party claimed that by disowning tariffs and restrictions imposed by the [[European Union Customs Union]] (EUCU) the UK could focus on adopting amicable [[Commonwealth free trade|free trade with]] the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. The party would have further sought to reduce unemployment by limiting the proportion of migrant work imported from [[Member state of the European Union|EU member states]], as well as attempted to lower [[Council Tax]] by scrapping the fiscal implications of the union's [[Landfill Directive]]. Independence from Europe claimed that by abandoning the EU, and thus the cost of membership, the UK's national debt could have been cleared. Domestic budgetary policies included the raising of [[personal allowance]] to [[Pound sterling|£]]15,000, broad simplification of both [[Taxation in the United Kingdom#Personal taxes|personal]] and [[United Kingdom corporation tax|corporate]] tax and opposition to [[Zero-hour contract|zero-hours contracts]]. In addition, the party condoned the forced collection of tax from [[Tax evasion|evaders]] and the [[nationalisation]] of [[private finance initiative]]s (PFIs). ===Energy, environment and transport policy=== [[File:West Ruislip station MMB 31.jpg|thumb|Scrapping plans for the [[High Speed 2]] (HS2) railway has been described among the party's "key policies".]] The party opposed government subsidy of [[wind turbine]]s and instead proposed the increased use of [[clean coal technology]] and [[nuclear fusion]] to address the UK's energy shortage. This would have been accompanied by a state-owned 'Public British Energy Company', a measure that the party hoped would keep consumer costs affordable. The party would also have abandoned catch quotas set by the EU's [[Common Fisheries Policy]] and established 'no fishing zones' to ensure plentiful [[Fish stock|stocks]]. In transport policy, Independence from Europe was generally skeptical of large-scale developments. [[BBC News]] characterised the group's opposition to the construction of the [[High Speed 2]] (HS2) railway as among "[i]ts key policies"; the group further warned against expansion of London's [[London Stansted Airport|Standsted]] and [[Gatwick Airport|Gatwick]] airports, as well as the [[Expansion of Heathrow Airport#Third runway and sixth terminal|introduction of a third runway]] at [[Heathrow Airport|Heathrow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/pdf/Transport_Policy_NOV%202013.pdf |title=Transport for an Independent Britain: A 10 Point Policy Statement |publisher=Independence from Europe |page=5 |accessdate=16 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qVREe4o0?url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/pdf/Transport_Policy_NOV%202013.pdf |archivedate=16 May 2017 |df= }} Furthermore, the party sought to abolish [[Toll roads in Great Britain|toll roads]] and nationalise [[Passenger rail franchising in Great Britain|UK railway franchises]] "if they fail[ed] in viability or in their contractual obligations." ===Foreign, defence and immigration policy=== The group sought to re-establish "traditional links" with the Commonwealth of Nations, believing that the UK had "lost invaluable trading links, respect and friendship" with the organisation since joining the EU. Independence from Europe twice asserted that the UK misspends foreign aid on countries wealthy enough to fund independent [[Space policy|space programs]], it suggested such funding should be diverted to support Britain's elderly population. In defence policy, the party pledged to increase the number of [[British Armed Forces|armed forces]] personnel to 200,000 and reduce the amount of British troops sent to fight abroad, further encouraging the [[United Nations]] (UN) to take more responsibility over international security. Independence from Europe called for stricter immigration policy to be implemented in the UK, but refused to set a statistical migration target. It supported an 'Australian-style' points-based system to regulate immigration once the UK had left the [[European Economic Area]] (EEA),{{efn|Australia issues [[Travel visa|visas]] to candidates who accumulate an acceptable amount of 'points' to be considered a skilled migrant; points are conditional on criteria such as age, competency in the [[English language]], qualifications and current/past occupation(s).Davidson, Helen {{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jun/01/what-is-australia-points-based-immigration-system-brexit |title=What is Australia's points-based immigration system? |work=The Guardian |date=1 June 2016 |accessdate=25 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qi8klLgh?url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jun/01/what-is-australia-points-based-immigration-system-brexit |archivedate=25 May 2017 |df= }}}} citing pressures on population growth, housing and infrastructure. Foreigners would also have faced more stringent rules once they had arrived; temporary visitors would have had to carry [[Identity document#United Kingdom|identification]] at all times, as well as resided in the UK for at least 10 years before becoming eligible for British citizenship. Such measures, the party hoped, would justify the reintroduction of the country's [[Work permit (United Kingdom)|work permit scheme]]. ===Social policy=== The party supported the maintenance of Britain's [[National Health Service]] (NHS) to be free at the point of delivery and described itself as "dead against privatisation" of the institution. Whilst reducing bureaucracy in the NHS, the party would also have aimed to invest a further £5 billion to train 40,000 more nurses in addition to 10,000 extra doctors. Free dental and eye treatment would have been restored and foreign visitors would be required to possess [[Health insurance|private medical insurance]] during their time in the UK. It sought to return more community services, like the NHS, into public ownership where they had been privatised entirely or in-part, including [[Her Majesty's Prison Service|prisons]] and the [[Post Office Ltd|Post Office]]. It would have reserved the [[Welfare state in the United Kingdom|UK's wider welfare system]] to cater exclusively for British citizens; they would also have limited the amount of [[tax credit]]s a childless, able-bodied citizen could receive to 80% of the weekly [[Minimum wage|national minimum wage]] as well as restricted [[Child benefits in the United Kingdom|child benefit]] payments for households with more than two juveniles and/or a combined annual income of over £50,000. Independence from Europe supported and sought to extend tenants' '[[Right to Buy]]' [[Council house|council]] and [[housing association]] properties. To address crime, the party sought to deport foreign offenders, extend [[Neighborhood watch|neighborhood watch schemes]] and hold a referendum on restoring [[Capital punishment in the United Kingdom|capital punishment in the UK]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/AIPvUKIP.php |title=How AIP Differs from UKIP |publisher=Independence from Europe |accessdate=30 May 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6qqtORY9t?url=http://www.aipmep.org/Policies/AIPvUKIP.php |archivedate=30 May 2017 |df= }} It further pledged to invest £2.5 billion into the [[Law enforcement in the United Kingdom|police service]], promising to recruit 10,000 more [[Police officer|officers]]. In addition, the group would have reformed education policy by aiming to cut school class sizes and scrapping [[Tuition fees in the United Kingdom|tuition fees]] for UK students attending [[Universities in the United Kingdom|British universities]]; conversely, all foreign students would have been required to pay in full. ==See also== * [[Independence from Europe election results]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{Notelist}} ===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} * {{Cite book |last=Blaney|first=Donal|editor=Dale, Iain (ed.).|editorlink=Iain Dale|section=Election dysfunction? Internal Security Service |nativename = جهاز الأمن الداخلي |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Coat of arms of Oman.svg |logo_width = 120px |logo_caption = [[National Emblem of Oman]] |formed = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Oman]] and its national security (internal)
{{flagicon|Oman}} |headquarters = [[Qurum]], Muscat Governate, Sultanate of Oman |coordinates = |chief1_name = Lt Gen Said bin Ali al Hilali |chief1_position = Head of ISS |chief2_name = Maj Gen Ghosn bin Hilal al Alawi |chief2_position = Assistant Head of ISS |parent_agency = [[Palace Office (Oman)|The Palace Office]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = }} '''Internal Security Service ''' ('''ISS'''; {{lang-ar|'''جهاز الأمن الداخلي'''}}) [[Romanization of Arabic|transliterated]]:''' ''Jahaz al Amn al Dakhly''''', is the [[national security]] agency of the Sultanate of [[Oman]].{{cite web|title=Internal Security Service|url=http://www.oman.om/wps/portal/!ut/p/a0/04_Sj9CPykssy0xPLMnMz0vMAfGjzOKNDdwNDPwtPX1NnAJdDIy8jLxNgx2NjQyCTfSDM0viPUP0C7IdFQFFnssd/?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/EN/site/home/gov/gov1/gov5governmentorganizations/iss/|website=www.oman.om|accessdate=7 July 2017|language=it-IT}} The agency focuses solely upon domestic security while foreign intelligence operations is specifically handled by the [[Palace Office (Oman)|Palace Office]], which controls external security and coordinates all intelligence and security policies.{{cite web|title=Oman, Page 3|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/186654.pdf|publisher=US DOS|accessdate=7 July 2017}} The stated overall purpose of ISS is to investigates all matters related to internal security.{{cite web|title=Oman|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27935.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=7 July 2017}}{{cite news|title=Oman's Internal Security Service launches its official website|url=http://timesofoman.com/article/96874/Oman/Government/Oman's-Internal-Security-Service-launches-its-official-website|accessdate=7 July 2017|work=Times of Oman}}{{cite web|title=Oman: Internal Security Service continues systematic targeting of human rights defenders & Internet activists|url=http://www.gc4hr.org/news/view/1561|website=www.gc4hr.org|accessdate=7 July 2017}} The ISS also leads on Omani counter terrorism procedures and outreach activities.{{cite book|last1=Gunaratna|first1=Rohan|last2=Ali|first2=Mohamed Bin|title=Terrorist Rehabilitation: A New Frontier in Counter-terrorism|date=2015|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=9781783267453|page=16|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0dy3CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA16&lpg=PA16&dq=address+%22ISS%22+security+Oman#v=onepage&q=address%20%22ISS%22%20security%20Oman&f=false|accessdate=7 July 2017|language=en}} The ISS can trace its history back to the intelligence and security structures set up using British military intelligence expertise as part of Sultan Said's armed forces in the 1950s.{{cite journal|last1=Eickelman|first1=Dale F.|last2=Dennison|first2=M. G.|title=Arabizing the Omani intelligence services: Clash of cultures?|journal=International Journal of Intelligence and CounterIntelligence|date=1 March 1994|volume=7|issue=1|pages=1–28|doi=10.1080/08850609408435235|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08850609408435235?journalCode=ujic20|accessdate=7 July 2017|issn=0885-0607}} HM Sultan Qaboos developed the capability and the Oman Intelligence Service became the Oman Research Department (ORD); with its main focus being supporting counter insurgency operations in the Dhofar Region in the 1970s.{{cite book|last1=Macris|first1=Jeffrey|last2=Kelly|first2=Saul|title=Imperial Crossroads: The Great Powers and the Persian Gulf|date=2012|publisher=Naval Institute Press|isbn=9781612510941|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rxb1N3kxz24C&pg=PT137&lpg=PT137&dq=ORD+Dhofar#v=onepage&q=ORD%20Dhofar&f=false|accessdate=7 July 2017|language=en}}{{cite journal|last1=Jones|first1=Clive|title=Military Intelligence, Tribes, and Britain's War in Dhofar, 1970-1976|journal=Middle East Journal|date=2011|volume=65|issue=4|pages=557–574|jstor=41342740}}{{cite book|last1=Allen|first1=Calvin H.|last2=II|first2=W. Lynn Rigsbee|title=Oman Under Qaboos: From Coup to Constitution, 1970-1996|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135314309|page=91|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lLujAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&dq=ORD+Dhofar#v=onepage&q=ORD%20Dhofar&f=false|accessdate=7 July 2017|language=en}} The ORD was re-titled the ISS in 1987.Ibid p91 The ISS is known to have offices in [[Qurum]] (in the Capital area){{cite book|last1=Peterson|first1=John|title=Historical Muscat: An Illustrated Guide and Gazetteer|date=2007|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9004152660|page=24|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gNu4_uHo7CQC&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=Internal+Security+Service+Oman+Qurum#v=onepage&q=Internal%20Security%20Service%20Oman%20Qurum&f=false|accessdate=7 July 2017|language=en}} and [[Salalah]] in [[Dhofar]].{{cite web|title=Projects {{!}} Al Amana Co. LLC|url=http://alamana.om/projects/|website=alamana.om|accessdate=7 July 2017}}{{cite web|title=Oman Yellow Pages|url=http://www.omantel-yellowpages.com/wap/MinDetails.aspx?id=25|website=www.omantel-yellowpages.com|accessdate=7 July 2017}} In 1994 and 2005 there were attempted coups against the Sultan's rule and the ISS would have been instrumental in uncovering and investigating the plots.{{cite web|title=Oman Is Immune from Terrorist Groups|url=https://chronicle.fanack.com/oman/history-past-to-present/oman-immune-from-terrorism/|website=Fanack Chronicle|accessdate=7 July 2017}}{{cite web|title=Oman sentences members of secret group between one to 20 years 02/05/2005|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticlePrintPage.aspx?id=1563531&language=en|website=www.kuna.net.kw|publisher=KUNA|accessdate=7 July 2017}}{{cite web|title=BBC NEWS Middle East Oman jails 31 for plotting coup|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4505075.stm|website=news.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=7 July 2017}} As of May 2013, Lieutenant General Said bin Ali bin Zahir al Hilali was appointed Head of the ISS{{cite news|last1=Newspaper|first1=Muscat Daily|title=His Majesty the Sultan appoints new head of Internal Security Service - Oman|url=http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Oman/His-Majesty-the-Sultan-appoints-new-head-of-Internal-Security-Service-29z8|accessdate=7 July 2017|work=Muscat Daily News|language=en}} - he had formerly been the Assistant Head of the agency. He was still in post as of November 2015.{{cite web|title=Times of Oman 10 Nov 2015|url=https://www.pressreader.com/oman/times-of-oman/20151110/281569469612080|website=www.pressreader.com|accessdate=7 July 2017}} His former post was passed to Brigadier Ghosn bin Hilal bin Khalifa al Alawi (who was promoted to major general on assuming the post of Assistant Head ISS).{{cite news|last1=Report|first1=Staff|title=New chief for internal security in Oman|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/new-chief-for-internal-security-in-oman-1.1186473|accessdate=7 July 2017|work=GulfNews|date=21 May 2013}} Lieutenant General Said al Hilali's brother is the Sultanate's Public Prosecutor, who was reported in 2012 to be ready to use the law to restrict freedom of speech and association.{{cite web|last1=Valeri|first1=Marc|title=Simmering Unrest and Succession Challenges in Oman|url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2015/01/28/simmering-unrest-and-succession-challenges-in-oman-pub-58843|website=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|accessdate=7 July 2017}} ==See also== * HM Sultan [[Qaboos bin Said al Said]] * The [[Dhofar Rebellion]] * The [[Dhofar Liberation Front]] * [[Human rights in Oman]] * [[Royal Oman Police]] ==References== {{Ibid|date=April 2018}} {{reflist|30em}} {{Domestic national intelligence agencies}} [[Category:Law enforcement in Oman]] [[Category:Intelligence agencies]] [[Category:National security]]

The '''International League of Esperanto Teachers''' ({{lang-eo|Internacia Ligo de Esperantistaj Instruistoj}}, '''ILEI''') is a [[non-governmental organization]] which teaches respect for humanity, life and nature and which seeks to further mutual understanding among peoples. The group advocates the spread of [[Esperanto]] language and [[Esperanto culture|culture]], publishes books and journals, organizes international conferences and administers examinations worldwide to certify the qualifications of Esperanto teachers. ILEI is a special interest group affiliated with both [[UNESCO]] and the [[Universal Esperanto Association]] (UEA).
==History== Founded in 1949, the first executive council included [[Violet C. Nixon]], ([[United Kingdom]], president), [[Einar Dahl (Esperantist)|Einar Dahl]] ([[Sweden]], secretary-treasurer), [[Jeanne Dedieu]] ([[France]]) and [[P. Korte]] ([[Netherlands]]).<ref>''Internacia Ligo de Esperantistaj Instruistoj stariĝis'' in [http://www.gazetoteko.eu/jv/jv4909.pdf ''La Juna Vivo,'' September 1949], page 355.</ref> Subsequent ILEI presidents have included [[István Szerdahelyi]] (1985–1988), [[Edward Symoens]] (1988–1991), [[Stefan MacGill]] (1991–1993), [[Duncan Charters]] (1993–1998), [[Mauro La Torre]] (1998–2003), [[Radojica Petrovic]] (2003–2009); [[Stefan MacGill]] (2009-2013) and [[Mireille Grosjean]] (2013-) <ref>[http://www.ilei.info/ipr/estraro.htm ILEI Estraro]. Retrieved 2009-07-20.</ref>
==Conferences== ILEI holds conferences, usually every year, with particular themes devoted to culture, tourism and linguistic festivals;<ref>[http://www.ilei.info/agado/index.php?lingvo=eo ILEI conferences] (eo)</ref> most conferences have been in [[Europe]], though [[Cuba]], [[South Korea]], [[Australia]], [[Japan]] and [[Benin]] have also hosted conferences.<ref name=conf>[http://www.ilei.info/agado/konferencoj.pdf Conferences 1976-2008] (eo)</ref>

The '''Kissinger Lecture on Foreign Policy and International Relations''' is an annual lecture given by an invited speaker at the [[Library of Congress]], [[Washington D.C.]] It was established in 2001 to honor [[Henry Kissinger]], the former [[United States Secretary of State]], along with the annual [[Kissinger Scholar]] as holder of the ''Henry Alfred Kissinger Chair in Foreign Policy and International Relations'' that was established in 2000.
The lectures have been given by: * Henry Kissinger, Inaugural Lecture 2001 * [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]], 2003 * [[George Shultz]], 2004 * [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]], 2005 * [[James Baker]], 2007

{{Liberalism sidebar}} '''Liberism''' (derived from the [[Italian language|Italian]] term ''liberismo'') is a term for the [[Economics|economic doctrine]] of ''[[laissez-faire]]'' [[capitalism]] first used by the philosopher [[Benedetto Croce]]{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} and popularized in [[English language|English]] by the [[Italian-American]] [[Political science|political scientist]] [[Giovanni Sartori]].
Sartori imported the term from Italian in order to distinguish between [[social liberalism]], which is generally considered a [[political ideology]] often advocating extensive government intervention in the economy; and those [[Economic liberalism|liberal theories of economics]] which propose to virtually eliminate such intervention. In informal usage, liberism overlaps with other concepts such as [[free trade]], [[neoliberalism]], [[right-libertarianism]], the [[United States|American]] concept of [[libertarianism]] and the [[French language|French]] notion of ''laissez-faire''.
In Italy, liberism is often identified with the [[Political philosophy|political theories]] of [[Gaetano Mosca]], [[Luigi Einaudi]] and [[Bruno Leoni]]. Internationally, liberism has been advocated by the [[Austrian School]] of economic theory, for instance by [[Ludwig von Mises]] and [[Friedrich von Hayek]].
== Sources == * Giovanni Sartori. ''The Theory of Democracy Revisited'' (1987). Chatham, New Jersey. Chatham House. {{ISBN|0-934540-49-7}}.

'''Liberty or death''', alternatively '''independence or death''', is a slogan made famous during the independence struggle of several countries, notably the United States of America, Brazil, Bulgaria, Greece, Romania, Serbia, Turkey, Ireland, and Uruguay.
'''Liberty or death''' may refer to:
== Patriotic slogans == *''[[Eleftheria i thanatos]]'' ("freedom or death"), national motto of Greece, derived from the 1821 Greek War of Independence * "[[Give me Liberty, or give me Death!]]", a quotation attributed to Patrick Henry near the start of the American Revolution. *''Independência ou morte'' ("independence or death"), motto of the [[Empire of Brazil]] (1822–89). *''Libertad o Muert''" ("Liberty or Death"), national motto of [[Uruguay]], taken from the Cisplatine War in 1825. *''Sloboda ili smrt'' or ''Слобода или смрт'' ("freedom or death"), motto of the Serbian [[chetniks]]. *''Viața-n libertate ori moarte'' ("Life in freedom or death!"), a shout proclaimed in the [[national anthem of Romania]]. * ''Свобода или смърт'' or ''Svoboda ili smârt'', slogan used by the Bulgarian [[komitadjis]]. * ''Ya istiklal ya ölüm'' ("independence or death"), the national motto of Turkey.
== Other uses == *[[GNU General Public License#Version 2]], nicknamed "Liberty or Death" *[[Liberty or Death (album)|''Liberty or Death'' (album)]], a 2007 album by the band Grave Digger. *[[Liberty or Death (video game)|''Liberty or Death'' (video game)]], a 1993 video game based on the American Revolutionary War. *''Liberty or Death: The American Insurrection'', a 2016 board game published by [[GMT Games]].
==See also== * ''[[Captain Michalis]]'', a 1953 Greek novel by Nikos Kazantzakis titled as ''Freedom or Death'' in the US edition and ''Freedom and Death'' in the UK edition. * [[Give Me Liberty (disambiguation)]] * [[Independence or Death (painting)|''Independence or Death'' (painting)]], 1888 Brazilian painting by Pedro Américo * [[Live Free or Die]], the state motto of New Hampshire * [[Samuel Sharpe]], the leader of a slave revolt in Jamaica, reportedly said before being hanged: "I would rather die among yonder gallows, than live in slavery." * [[Troutman flag]], used by the Georgia battalion during Texas revolution.

revision.text:
{{POV|date=May 2013}} This is a partial list of allegations of misuse of the United States [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS), which traces its roots to the creation of the [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue]] in 1862. Examples of political profiling controversies include cases in which IRS employees or government officials have allegedly used IRS resources to target individuals and groups for espousing or expressing particular political beliefs.
== 1930s ==
Use of the IRS for political targeting has been alleged as far back as the [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] administration.
:“My father,” [[Elliott Roosevelt]] observed of his famous parent, “may have been the originator of the concept of employing the IRS as a weapon of political retribution.”<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=HwTPk00QMHIC&pg=PA146&lpg=PA146&dq=%E2%80%9Cmay+have+been+the+originator+of+the+concept+of+employing+the+IRS+as+a+weapon+of+political+retribution.%E2%80%9C&source=bl&ots=5wz0QI69fL&sig=BE2PbH1Ad4E52vnnamVIe_68W1s&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BeWUUYLPD4eJ4ASkwIHoAg&ved=0CDEQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%E2%80%9Cmay%20have%20been%20the%20originator%20of%20the%20concept%20of%20employing%20the%20IRS%20as%20a%20weapon%20of%20political%20retribution.&f=false New Deal Or Raw Deal?: How FDR's Economic Legacy Has Damaged America By Burton W. Folsom, Jr. Chapter 11:"The IRS, FDR's personal weapon". ]</ref>
== 1940s-1960s ==
The most famous Kennedy administration project allegedly deploying tax-related targeting was called the "Ideological Organizations Project". This was a project which allegedly investigated, intimidated, and challenged the tax-exempt status of right-wing foundations.<ref name="amazon2002">[https://www.amazon.com/Power-Destroy-Political-Kennedy-Nixon/dp/1566634520/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1368521622&sr=8-1&keywords=irs+political Andrew, John A., III (2002) Power to Destroy: The Political Uses of the IRS from Kennedy to Nixon ]</ref>
Many instances of alleged political profiling were coordinated with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI), sometimes under [[COINTELPRO]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Scherer |first=Michael |url=http://swampland.time.com/2013/05/14/anger-over-irs-audits-of-conservatives-anchored-in-long-history-of-abuse/#ixzz2TMyxsVPZ |title=IRS Scandal Echoes a Long History of Political Harassment | TIME.com |publisher=Swampland.time.com |date= 14 May 2013|accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref> The IRS provided the FBI with free access to tax returns, which the FBI used to investigate groups as ideologically varied as the [[John Birch Society]], the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]], and the [[American Communist Party]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/lists/irs-scandal/american_communists.html?state=stop |title=History of IRS Abuse: American Communists |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Real Clear Politics |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref>
Beginning in the 1950s and continuing into the 1960s, the IRS audited civil rights leader [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] numerous times.<ref name="burnham">{{cite journal |last=Burnham |first=David |year=1989 |title=MISUSE OF THE I.R.S.: THE ABUSE OF POWER |journal=The New York Times Magazine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/03/magazine/misuse-of-the-irs-the-abuse-of-power.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/lists/irs-scandal/martin_luther_king.html?state=stop |title=History of IRS Abuse: Martin Luther King Jr. |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Real Clear Politics |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref> In addition to King himself, the [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] and several of King's lawyers were subjected to audits.
==Nixon== {{main|Watergate scandal}} In 1974, a Bill of Impeachment against President [[Richard Nixon]] was approved by the [[House Judiciary Committee]] that included charges that his administration attempted to use the IRS in a discriminatory manner: : :RESOLVED, That Richard M. Nixon, President of the United States, is impeached for high crimes and misdemeanours... : :Using the powers of the office of President of the United States, Richard M. Nixon, in violation of his constitutional oath faithfully to execute the office of President of the United States... : :He has, acting personally and through his subordinates and agents, endeavoured to... cause, in violation of the constitutional rights of citizens, income tax audits or other income tax investigations to be intitiated or conducted in a discriminatory manner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://watergate.info/impeachment/articles-of-impeachment |title=Watergate Articles Of Impeachment |publisher=Watergate.info |date= |accessdate=2013-05-14}}</ref>
== Clinton == Conservative groups including the [[Heritage Foundation]], the [[National Rifle Association]], and [[Judicial Watch]] alleged that the [[Bill Clinton administration|Clinton administration]] subjected them to politically motivated audits.<ref name="rcp1">{{cite web |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/lists/irs-scandal/paula_corbin_jones.html?state=stop |title=History of IRS Abuse: Paula Corbin Jones |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=Real Clear Politics |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref>
==G. W. Bush ==
The NAACP was audited in 2004 after its chairman criticized then-President [[George W. Bush]] for failing to address the group, becoming the first president to do so since [[Herbert Hoover]].<ref name="naacp1">{{cite news |title=NAACP blames tax audit on criticism of Bush |author=Kelly Brewington |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2004-10-29/news/0410290318_1_tax-exempt-organizations-audit-naacp |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |date=29 October 2004 |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref> The IRS informed the NAACP that the audit was prompted by then-NAACP-chairman [[Julian Bond]]'s speech, which "condemned the administration policies of George W. Bush on education, the economy and the war in Iraq."<ref name="naacp2">{{cite news |title=Democrats denounce IRS audit of NAACP |author=Kelly Brewington |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2004-10-30/news/0410300223_1_naacp-bond-tax-exempt-status |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |date=30 October 2004 |accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref> Although the IRS maintained that the audit was an attempt to determine whether the NAACP had involved itself in a political campaign, the NAACP and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] representatives characterized the audit as an attempt to stifle criticism of Bush, intimidate NAACP members, and harm the NAACP's get-out-the-vote campaign.<ref name="naacp1" /><ref name=naacp2 />
According to the ''[[Huffington Post]]'' in 2004, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that the IRS audited the liberal group [[Greenpeace]] at the request of [[Public Interest Watch]], a group funded by Exxon-Mobil. <ref>{{cite news |author=Bob Cesca |title=10 Examples of Bush and the Republicans Using Government Power to Target Critics |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-cesca/10-examples-of-bush-and-t_b_3288007.html |newspaper=Huffington Post |date=16 May 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2015 }}</ref> Exxon-Mobil said it was not aware of the IRS audit, nor did it have a role in initiating the audit.<ref>{{cite news |author=Steve Stecklow |title=Did a Group Financed by Exxon Prompt IRS to Audit Greenpeace? |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB114291044305003774 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=21 March 2006 |accessdate=24 January 2015 }}</ref>
According to the ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]'' ''PolitiFact'' the allegation that the IRS during the Bush Administration targeted liberal groups is "Mostly False".<ref>{{cite news |author=Jon Greenberg |title=IRS targeted liberal groups during Bush years, says Jim McDermott |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2013/jun/06/jim-mcdermott/irs-targeted-liberal-groups-bush-years-jim-mcdermo/ |newspaper=Tampa Bay Times |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2015 }}</ref>
== Obama ==
{{main|IRS targeting controversy}}
In May 2013, the IRS admitted it had subjected conservative political groups to closer scrutiny in their applications for tax-exempt status based on particular keywords in their names. The agency has maintained that low-level employees took it upon themselves to do this. However, Republicans argue that the refusal of [[Lois Lerner]] (at the time was Director of the IRS's Exempt Organizations Unit) to testify before Congress, twice citing her Constitutional right against self-incrimination, suggests involvement by higher-level employees. An internal report by the agency's Inspector General cited "ineffective management" as the cause and indicated that the IRS "will need to do more so that the public has reasonable assurance that applications are processed without unreasonable delay in a fair and impartial manner in the future." <ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Business/irs-irs-long-history-dirty-tricks/story?id=19177178]</ref> Congress continues to investigate the possibility that Lerner or other high-level officials were involved in improper political targeting. Republican lawmakers say the IRS has improperly withheld and destroyed evidence, while Democrats argue that Republicans are attempting to keep the controversy alive for political purposes.
