{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{about|the austerity programme in the 21st century|austerity during the years immediately following World War II|Social history of the United Kingdom (1945–present)#Age of Austerity}} [[File:Uk incomes.png|thumb|300px|UK median household disposable income by income group for 2008–2016, indexed to 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/personalandhouseholdfinances/incomeandwealth/bulletins/householddisposableincomeandinequality/financialyearending2016|title=Household disposable income and inequality in the UK: financial year ending 2016|author=|date=10 January 2017|publisher=Office for National Statistics}}</ref>]] The '''United Kingdom government austerity programme''' is a [[fiscal policy]] adopted in the early 21st century following the [[Great Recession]]. It is a deficit reduction programme consisting of sustained reductions in public spending and tax rises, intended to reduce the [[government budget deficit]] and the role of the [[welfare state in the United Kingdom]]. The [[National Health Service]]<ref>{{cite web|title=NHS funding protected?|url=http://www.nhscampaign.org/NHS-reforms/no-cuts-to-nhs-budget.html|publisher=NHS Support Federation|accessdate=19 May 2017}}</ref> and education<ref>{{cite news|title=School spending stays protected from budget cuts|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-23063018|publisher=BBC News|date=26 June 2013}}</ref> have been "[[Ringfencing|ringfenced]]" and protected from direct spending cuts.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22363650 |title=Should NHS budget be ring-fenced?|publisher=BBC News|date=1 May 2013|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> The [[#Effects|effects]] of United Kingdom [[austerity]] policies have proved [[#Reaction|controversial]] and the policies have received criticism from a variety of politicians and economists. [[Anti-austerity movement]]s have been formed among citizens more generally.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web|last1=Krugman|first1=Paul|title=The Austerity Delusion|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/ng-interactive/2015/apr/29/the-austerity-delusion|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
==History== A UK government [[budget surplus]] in 2001–2 was followed by many years of [[budget deficit]]<ref name=Partington>{{cite newspaper|newspaper=The Guardian|title=UK government deficit widens unexpectedly in August|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/sep/21/uk-government-deficit-widens-for-first-time-in-three-years|author=Richard Partington |date=21 September 2018}}</ref> and after the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]] a period of economic [[recession]] began in the country. The first austerity measures were introduced in late 2008.<ref name=Nevin>{{cite web|title=Austerity in Northern Ireland. Where are we and where are we going?|url=https://www.nerinstitute.net/blog/2015/05/06/austerity-in-northern-ireland-where-are-we-and-whe/|publisher=Nevin Economic Research Institute|author=Paul Mac Flynn|date=6 May 2015}}</ref> In 2009, the term ''age of austerity'', which had previously been used to describe the years immediately following [[World War II]],<ref>{{cite book|first=David |last=Kynaston|title=Austerity Britain, 1945-1951|url={{google books|plainurl=y|id=q7zQx0VRTkgC}}|year=2010|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-0-8027-7958-8|ref=harv}}</ref> was popularised by Conservative Party leader [[David Cameron]]. In his keynote speech to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] forum in [[Cheltenham]] on 26 April 2009 he declared that "the age of irresponsibility is giving way to the age of austerity" and committed to end years of what he characterised as excessive government spending.<ref>{{cite web|title=From Austerity to Inequality|url=http://www.nicva.org/article/austerity-inequality|publisher=NICVA|accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Deborah Summers |title= David Cameron warns of 'new age of austerity' |url= https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/apr/26/david-cameron-conservative-economic-policy1|work=The Guardian |accessdate=26 April 2009 | location=. |date=26 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429083220/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/apr/26/david-cameron-conservative-economic-policy1| archivedate= 29 April 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=M. Nicolas Firzli & Vincent Bazi |title= Infrastructure Investments in an Age of Austerity : The Pension and Sovereign Funds Perspective|url= http://www.turkishweekly.net/op-ed/2852/infrastructure-investments-in-an-age-of-austerity-the-pension-and-sovereign-funds-perspective.html| work=Revue Analyse Financière, volume 41 |edition= Q4 2011 |accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref> The austerity programme was initiated in 2010 by the [[Cameron–Clegg coalition|Conservative and Liberal Democrat coalition government]]. In his [[June 2010 United Kingdom budget|June 2010 budget]] speech, the Chancellor [[George Osborne]] identified two goals. The first was that the structural current budget deficit would be eliminated to "achieve [a] cyclically-adjusted current balance by the end of the rolling, five-year forecast period". The second was that [[Government debt|national debt]] as a percentage of [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] would be falling. The government intended to achieve both of its goals through substantial reductions in public expenditure.<ref name=Nevin/> This was to be achieved by a combination of public spending reductions and tax increases amounting to £110 billion.<ref name=Chu>{{cite AV media |people=Ben Chu |date=6 July 2017 |title=Austerity: Is it really over? |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/austerity-end-over-tories-pay-cap-what-is-it-over-public-spending-explained-a7825726.html |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> The end of the forecast period was 2015–16.
Between 2010 and 2013, the [[Cameron-Clegg coalition|Coalition government]] said that it had reduced public spending by £14.3 billion compared with 2009–10.<ref name=Merrick>{{cite news|title=Chancellor Philip Hammond accused of more 'failed austerity' after demanding extra spending cuts before the election|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/chancellor-philip-hammond-latest-budget-spending-cuts-austerity-social-care-john-mcdonnell-a7603096.html|author=Rob Merrick|date=28 February 2017|newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> Growth remained low during this period, while unemployment rose.<ref name=Chu/> In a speech in 2013, David Cameron indicated that his government had no intention of increasing public spending once the structural deficit had been eliminated and proposed that the public spending reduction be made permanent.<ref>{{cite news|title=David Cameron makes leaner state a permanent goal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/nov/11/david-cameron-policy-shift-leaner-efficient-state|date=12 November 2013|author=Nicholas Watt|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> In 2014, the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] extended the proposed austerity period until at least 2018.<ref>{{cite news|author=James Kirkup|title=George Osborne to cut taxes by extending austerity and creating smaller state|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/georgeosborne/10552454/George-Osborne-to-cut-taxes-by-extending-austerity-and-creating-smaller-state.html|date=5 January 2014|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> By 2015, the deficit, as a percentage of GDP, had been reduced to half of what it was in 2010, and the sale of government assets (mostly the shares of banks nationalised in the 2000s) had resulted in government debt as a proportion of GDP falling.<ref name=Nevin/> By 2016, the Chancellor was aiming to deliver a budget surplus by 2020, but following the result of the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]], he expressed the opinion that this goal was no longer achievable.<ref>{{cite news|title=Europe May Finally End Its Painful Embrace of Austerity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/08/business/international/europe-economy-budget-austerity.html|author=Peter S. Goodman|date=7 October 2016|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=17 October 2016}}</ref>
Osborne's successor as Chancellor, [[Philip Hammond]], retained the aim of a balanced budget<ref>{{cite news|title=Philip Hammond to ditch George Osborne's economic targets|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/03/philip-hammond-to-set-out-his-stall-for-balanced-budget-at-tory-conference|date=3 October 2016|author1=Peter Walker|author2=Rowena Mason|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> but abandoned plans to eliminate the deficit by 2020.<ref>{{cite news|title=Philip Hammond warns Britain's economy heading for post-Brexit 'rollercoaster' ride as he drops pledge for budget surplus by 2020|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/03/philip-hammond-budget-surplus-conservative-conference-live/|date=3 October 2016|author= Michael Wilkinson|newspaper=The Telegraph|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> In Hammond's first Autumn statement in 2016, there was no mention of austerity, and some commentators concluded that the austerity programme had ended.<ref name=Chalk>{{cite news|title=Whatever happened to austerity?|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/38092467/whatever-happened-to-austerity|date=24 November 2016|author=Will Chalk|work=BBC Newsbeat|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref><ref name=LSE>{{cite web|title=How does austerity look in retrospect? The UK’s recent fiscal squeeze in historical perspective|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/politicsandpolicy/how-does-austerity-look-in-retrospect/|publisher=The London School of Economics and Political Science|date=27 November 2016|author1=Christopher Hood|author2=Rozana Himaz|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> However, in February 2017, Hammond proposed departmental budget reductions of up to 6% for the year 2019–20,<ref name=Merrick/> and Hammond's 2017 budget continued government policies of freezing working-age benefits.<ref>{{cite news|author=Anoosh Chakelian|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/welfare/2017/03/what-welfare-changes-did-philip-hammond-make-his-budget-2017|title= What welfare changes did Philip Hammond make in his Budget 2017?|work=New Statesman|date=8 March 2017}}</ref> Following the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 snap general election]], Hammond confirmed in a speech at [[Mansion House, London|Mansion House]] that the austerity programme would be continued<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Philip Hammond insists he will stick with austerity|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3756dc5a-558e-11e7-9fed-c19e2700005f?mhq5j=e1|author1=George Parker|author2=Gavin Jackson|date=20 June 2017|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> and [[Michael Fallon]], the [[Secretary of State for Defence]], commented: "we all understand that austerity is never over until we've cleared the deficit".<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Michael Fallon defends £1bn DUP deal amid backlash|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/27/michael-fallon-defends-1bn-dup-deal-amid-backlash|date=27 June 2017|author1=Peter Walker|author2=Anushka Asthana|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Government spending reductions planned for the period 2017–2020 are consistent with some departments, such as the [[Department for Work and Pensions]] and the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Justice]], experiencing funding reductions of approximately 40% in [[real terms]] over the decade 2010–2020.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/nov/22/public-services-face-real-terms-spending-cuts-of-up-to-40-in-decade-to-2020|title=Public services face real-terms spending cuts of up to 40% in decade to 2020|author=Alan Travis|date=22 November 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> During 2017 an overall budget surplus on day-to-day spending was achieved for the first time since 2001. This fulfilled one of the fiscal targets set by George Osborne in 2010, which he had hoped to achieve in 2015.<ref name=":1">{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/03/01/back-black-uk-current-budget-surplus-imf-says-osborne-right/|title=Back in black: UK in current budget surplus as IMF says Osborne was right to cut spending|last=Wallace|first=Tim|date=1 March 2018|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=16 June 2018|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
In 2018 the [[Office for Budget Responsibility]] (OBR) predicted that in 2018–19 public sector debt would fall as a share of national income for the first time since 2001–02, while tax revenues would exceed public spending. Hammond's 2018 [[Spring Statement]] suggested that austerity measures could be reduced in the [[Budget of the United Kingdom|Autumn Budget]] of that year. However, according to the [[Resolution Foundation]] and the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] (IFS), the OBR's forecasts for borrowing and debt were based on the assumption that the government continued with the planned spending reductions that were announced after the 2015 general election. By 2018 only 25% of the proposed reductions in welfare spending had been implemented. The Resolution Foundation calculated that the proposed reduction in spending on working-age benefits amounted to £2.5 billion in 2018–19 and £2.7 billion in 2019–20, with the households most affected being the poorest 20%. The IFS calculated that the OBR's figures would require spending on public services per person in real terms to be 2% lower in 2022–23 than in 2019–20.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=UK will struggle to ease austerity in coming months, think-tanks warn|url=https://www.ft.com/content/b498f1fc-278f-11e8-b27e-cc62a39d57a0|newspaper=Financial Times|author=Gemma Tetlow|date=14 March 2018|access-date=15 March 2018}}</ref>
The deficit in the first quarter of the 2018–19 financial year was lower than at any time since 2007<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=UK deficit at lowest level since before financial crisis|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3b46d9dc-8bf7-11e8-b18d-0181731a0340|newspaper=Financial Times|author=Chris Giles|date=21 July 2018}}</ref> and by August 2018 it had reached the lowest level since 2002–3. Hammond's aim at this time was to eliminate the deficit entirely by the mid-2020s.<ref name=Partington/> At the Conservative Party conference in October 2018 Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] indicated her intention to end the austerity programme following [[Brexit]] in 2019<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Theresa May pledges end to austerity in Tory conference speech|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/03/theresa-may-conference-speech-ambasts-labour-as-she-calls-for-tory-unity|author=Heather Stewart|date=3 October 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> and opposition leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] said that austerity could not be ended without significant increases in public spending.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/10/jeremy-corbyn-theresa-may-claim-austerity-is-over-is-great-big-conservative-con-pmqs|title=Jeremy Corbyn: claim austerity is over is 'big Conservative con'|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Peter Walker|date=10 October 2018}}</ref> The IFS calculated that funding an end to austerity would require an additional £19 billion per year raised through higher government borrowing or tax increases.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hammond’s £19bn bill to 'end austerity'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-45863582|work=BBC News|date=16 October 2018|author=Kamal Ahmed}}</ref> Hammond's preference was to reduce the national debt with more years of austerity<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Philip Hammond: party must offer solutions to Labour questions|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/01/philip-hammond-vows-to-stick-with-austerity-in-conference-speech-amazon-google|author1=Phillip Inman|author2=Larry Elliott|date=1 October 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> but in the October 2018 budget he agreed to defer the target date for eliminating the deficit, abandoning plans to achieve a surplus in 2022–23 to allow an increase in health spending and tax cuts. The [[Resolution Foundation]] described the step as a "significant easing of austerity".<ref>{{cite newspaper|newspaper=Financial times|title=Hammond defends decision to delay balancing books|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0366271c-dc0f-11e8-9f04-38d397e6661c|author1=Jim Pickard|author2=George Parker|date=30 October 2018}}</ref> Hammond said that the "era of austerity is finally coming to an end"<ref>{{cite news|work=BBC News|title=Budget 2018: Austerity finally coming to an end, says Hammond|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46010550|date=29 October 2018}}</ref> but that there would be no "real terms" increase in public spending apart from on the NHS.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hammond v McDonnell on Budget 'end of austerity' claim|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-46024014|work=BBC News|date=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Effects== The austerity programme included reductions in welfare spending, the cancellation of school building programs, reductions in [[local government]] funding, and an increase in [[Value-added tax (United Kingdom)|VAT]].<ref name=Chu/> A number of [[quango]]s were abolished, merged or reduced as a result of the [[2010 UK quango reforms]].<ref>{{cite news|title=‘Bonfire of the quangos’ revealed|url=https://www.channel4.com/news/bonfire-of-the-quangos-promised|work=Channel 4 News|date=14 October 2010}}</ref>
===Demographics=== A number of independent reports have considered the demographic effects of the austerity programme. In 2011, activist collective [[Feminist Fightback]] described its gendered impact<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Feminist|first1=Fightack|title=Cuts Are a Feminist Issue|journal=Soundings Journal|date=15 December 2011|volume=Issue 49|issue= 49|url=http://www.newleftproject.org/index.php/site/article_comments/cuts_are_a_feminist_issue|accessdate=17 April 2016}}</ref> and in 2012 the [[Fawcett Society]] published a report which was critical of the Treasury for not assessing the impact of austerity on women's equality.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Impact of Austerity on Women|url=http://www.fawcettsociety.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/The-Impact-of-Austerity-on-Women-19th-March-2012.pdf|website=The Fawcett Society|publisher=The Fawcett Society|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> A 2015 report by the [[Resolution Foundation]] identified age-related disparities in the effects of austerity changes. The report projected that during the 2010s transfers to local authorities would fall by 64% and that spending on working-age welfare would fall by 71%, while between 1997 and 2020 spending on older people and health would rise from 33.8% to 43.4% of total government spending. In the same year a group of political scientists at the [[University of Nottingham]] found that the impact of austerity on in-work benefits and housing policy had been harmful to working families with children, while wealthy pensioners and older homeowners had benefited.<ref>{{Cite web|title = New research shows austerity is favouring older voters at the expense of the young|website=The Intergenerational Foundation|url = http://www.if.org.uk/archives/7348/new-research-shows-austerity-is-favouring-older-voters-at-the-expense-of-the-young|author=David Kingman|date=23 November 2015}}</ref> In 2016 research from the Women's Budget Group and the [[Runnymede Trust]] indicated that women, people of colour and in particular women of colour had been affected most by austerity, and that they would continue to be affected disproportionately until 2020. This was due to the fact that black and Asian women were more likely to be employed in the public sector, be in low-paid jobs and insecure work, and experience higher levels of unemployment than other groups.<ref>{{cite news|title=A toxic concoction means women of colour are hit hardest by austerity|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/nov/28/toxic-concoction-women-colour-pay-highest-price-austerity|author=Maya Goodfellow|date=28 November 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A cumulative gender impact assessment of ten years of austerity policies|url=http://wbg.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/De_HenauReed_WBG_GIAtaxben_briefing_2016_03_06.pdf|website=The Women's Budget Group|publisher=The Women's Budget Group|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref>
Research published in 2017 by the [[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]] identified an increase in [[child poverty]] and pensioner poverty compared to the previous year, following significant overall decreases during the previous 20 years. Reductions in benefit support and a shortage of affordable housing were considered to be contributing factors.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=UK government warned over sharp rise in child and pensioner poverty|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/dec/04/uk-government-warned-over-sharp-rise-children-pensioner-poverty-study|author=Richard Partington|newspaper=The Guardian|date=4 December 2017}}</ref>
===Food banks=== Researchers have linked budget cuts and sanctions against benefit claimants to increasing use of [[food banks]]. In a twelve-month period from 2014 to 2015, over one million people in the United Kingdom had used a food bank, representing a "19% year-on-year increase in food bank use".<ref>{{cite news| last=Butler|first=Patrick|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/apr/22/food-bank-users-uk-low-paid-workers-poverty|title=Food bank use tops million mark over the past year| newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
A study published in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]'' in 2015 found that each one percentage point increase in the rate of [[Jobseeker's Allowance]] claimants sanctioned was associated with a 0.09 percentage point rise in food bank use.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Loopstra|first1=Rachel|title=Austerity, sanctions, and the rise of food banks in the UK|journal=BMJ|date=2015|page=2|url=http://press.psprings.co.uk/bmj/april/foodbanks.pdf|accessdate=25 June 2015|doi=10.1136/bmj.h1775|volume=350|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626113008/http://press.psprings.co.uk/bmj/april/foodbanks.pdf|archive-date=26 June 2015|dead-url=yes}}</ref> However, the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] found that the number of people answering yes to the question "Have there been times in the past 12 months when you did not have enough money to buy food that you or your family needed?" decreased from 9.8% in 2007 to 8.1% in 2012,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/comment/columnists/leo-mckinstry/470840/Despite-the-Left-s-claims-over-soaring-foodbank-use-Britain-is-not-going-hungry |title=Despite the Left's claims over soaring foodbank use, Britain is not going hungry |last=McKinstry |first=Leo|date= |work=Daily Express|accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref> leading some to say that the rise was due to both more awareness of food banks, and the government allowing [[Jobcentre]]s to refer people to food banks when they were hungry, in contrast to previous governments.<ref name="blogs.spectator.co.uk">{{cite web|last=Young|first=Toby|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/2015/04/was-food-poverty-actually-higher-under-the-last-labour-government/ |title=Was food poverty actually higher under the last Labour government? |work= [[The Spectator]] |date=22 April 2015 |accessdate=11 November 2015}}</ref>
===Housing=== When the coalition government came to power in 2010, capital investment in new affordable homes was cut by 60%, while government-imposed caps on local authority borrowing continued to restrict their ability to raise money to build new homes.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=How do you fix a housing crisis in a time of austerity?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/housing-network/2015/mar/11/housing-crisis-time-austerity|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 March 2015}}</ref> Writing in ''[[Inside Housing]]'', former housing minister [[John Healey (politician)|John Healey]] observed that rate of starting social rented schemes had declined from 40,000 in 2009/10 to less than 1,000 in 2015/16.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comment: Time to end housing sector austerity|url=http://www.mulbury.co.uk/2016/09/comment-time-end-housing-sector-austerity/|publisher=Mulbury|date=1 September 2016|author=Greg Mulligan}}</ref> The number of people sleeping rough on any one night across England had more than doubled between 2010 and 2016 to an estimated 4,134, according to a government street count.<ref>{{cite news|title=2017: The year the full effects of austerity are felt|url=http://www.politics.co.uk/comment-analysis/2017/02/13/2017-the-year-the-full-effects-of-austerity-are-felt|date=13 February 2017|author=Natalie Bloomer|website=politics.co.uk}}</ref>
The [[benefit cap]], introduced via the [[Welfare Reform Act 2012]], set a maximum level for the amount of state welfare benefits that could be paid to an individual household in any one year. The measure came into effect in 2013 with the figure initially set at £26,000 per year, close to the average income of a family in the UK at that time. The anticipated reduction in government expenditure as a result of the measure was £225 million by April 2015.<ref name="bbc">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-26065080 | work=BBC News|title='Thousands' hit by government benefit cap now in work|date=6 February 2014}}</ref> The benefit cap initially affected approximately 12,000 households, mainly in high-rent areas of the UK such as London, but in 2016/17 the limit was reduced to £20,000 per annum (£23,000 in London) extending its effects to around 116,000 households across the UK.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Benefit cap will hit 116,000 of poorest families, say experts|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/nov/01/extended-benefit-cap-hit-116000-families-housing-experts|author=Patrick Butler|date=1 November 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
A [[Local Housing Allowance]] (LHA) policy restricting [[Housing Benefit]] for private sector tenants to cover a maximum number of rooms had been in place since 2008. It was extended in April 2013 to cover [[public housing in the United Kingdom]] (except Northern Ireland). The resulting [[under-occupancy penalty]], commonly known as the "bedroom tax", affected an estimated 660,000 working age social housing tenants in the UK, reducing weekly incomes by £12–£22.<ref name="Moffatt et al">{{cite journal|title=A qualitative study of the impact of the UK 'bedroom tax'|url=https://academic.oup.com/jpubhealth/article/38/2/197/1752995/A-qualitative-study-of-the-impact-of-the-UK|date=15 March 2015|author1=S. Moffatt|author2=S. Lawson|author3=R. Patterson|author4=E. Holding|author5=A. Dennison|author6=S. Sowden|author7=J. Brown|journal=Journal of Public Health|publisher=Oxford University Press|doi=10.1093/pubmed/fdv031|volume=38|issue=2|pages=197–205|pmc=4894481}}</ref> Almost two thirds of the people affected by the penalty were disabled.<ref>{{cite newspaper|last1=Ryan|first1=Frances|title='Bedroom tax' puts added burden on disabled people|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2013/jul/16/bedroom-tax-burden-disabled-people|newspaper=The Guardian|date=16 July 2013}}</ref> The measure reduced the expenditure of the [[Department for Work and Pensions]] by approximately £500 million per year.<ref>{{cite report|title=Impact of the under-occupation deduction from Housing Benefit (social housing)|url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/SN06896|date=19 February 2016|author1=Wendy Wilson|author2=Richard Keen|publisher=House of Commons Library (Briefing Paper)|page=7}}</ref>
From April 2016 the LHA rates used to calculate maximum housing benefit levels for private sector tenants were frozen for four years. Research by the housing charity [[Shelter (charity)|Shelter]] indicated that the proportion of such tenants likely to experience a shortfall in housing benefit was 80%, amounting to 300,000 families. The degree of shortfall depends on dwelling, location and individual circumstances, but Shelter expected that by 2020 the shortfall could in some cases reach hundreds of pounds a month.<ref>{{cite news|title=Low-income families in private housing face large benefit shortfalls|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/sep/10/low-income-families-private-housing-rent-benefit-freeze|date=10 September 2015|author=Patrick Butler|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
In April 2017, housing benefit payments were ended for new claims made by people aged 18–21. Research by [[Heriot-Watt University]] found that the policy would reduce annual government expenditure by £3.3 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Homelessness expected to rise further as Government scraps housing benefit for young people|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/housing-benefit-young-people-18-21-scrapped-universal-credit-exemptions-a7610581.html|date=3 March 2017|author=Jon Stone|newspaper=The Independent}}</ref>
During the period of austerity, the rate of homelessness has rapidly increased. For example, during 2016 the rate of homelessness increased by 16%. By 2018 the number of families living in bed and breakfast accommodation was almost 50,000, and there were many more "hidden homeless" people living on the floors and sofas of friends and acquaintances. An article in [[The BMJ]] regarded this as a "neon sign that something is fundamentally wrong" with how society is being run, noting that "homeless women die on average at 43 and homeless men at 47, compared with 77 for the rest of us".<ref name="Moffatt et al"/>
===Local government=== During the period of austerity there have been reductions in [[UK Government]] funding for [[county council]]s in England. This has combined with an increasing demand for [[social care]] services to cause reductions in expenditure on other services such as [[public libraries]], [[refuse collection]], [[road maintenance]] and [[Sure Start]], along with increases to [[council tax]] rates and the introduction of additional charges for county council services.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jun/27/english-councils-warn-worst-is-yet-to-come-on-cuts|title=English councils warn 'worst is yet to come' on cuts|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Patrick Butler |date=27 June 2018}}</ref> Local authority subsidies to bus services were reduced by almost half between 2010 and 2018.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jul/02/bus-services-in-crisis-as-councils-cut-funding-campaigners-warn|title=Bus services in 'crisis' as councils cut funding, campaigners warn|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Gwyn Topham|date=2 July 2018}}</ref>
Research by the [[Local Government Chronicle]] has indicated that between 2010 and 2018 there were more than 220,000 redundancies of local authority employees and nearly £4 billion was spent on redundancy payments, excluding [[outsourcing]] contracts. [[Rob Whiteman]] of [[CIPFA]] commented that "this scale of job losses reflects the intense financial pressure on councils as they now have no option other than to provide the bare minimum statutory provisions".<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/sep/13/councils-in-england-spend-4bn-on-220000-redundancies-since-2010|title=Councils in England spend £4bn on 220,000 redundancies since 2010|newspaper=The Guardian|date=13 September 2018|author=Patrick Butler}}</ref> Analysis by the [[Local Government Association]] in 2018 identified a decrease in the Revenue Support Grant for local authorities in England from £9,927 million in 2015–16 to £2,284 million for 2019–20, leaving 168 authorities with no grant for 2019–20.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=English councils brace for biggest government cuts since 2010 despite 'unprecedented' budget pressures|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/england-council-budget-cuts-government-austerity-social-services-essential-care-safety-a8559486.html|newspaper=Independent|author=May Bulman|date=1 October 2018}}</ref> UK government plans in 2018 proposed the phasing out of grants to local authorities in England, instead funding English local government through a combination of local [[Business rates in England|business rates]] and council tax.<ref name=Territorial>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/oct/09/territorial-injustice-on-rise-england-due-to-council-cuts-study|title='Territorial injustice' may rise in England due to council cuts|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Patrick Butler|date= 9 October 2018}}</ref>
Research by the [[University of Cambridge]] published in 2018 said that the greatest reductions in local authority spending had occurred in impoverished [[post-industrial]] cities in the north of England and some poor [[Inner London]] boroughs. Over 30 such authorities in England had reduced spending by more than 30% between 2010 and 2017, with seven of them reducing spending by more than 40%. In contrast councils in wealthier areas had made smaller reductions. Councils in England experienced an average spending reduction of 24% compared to 12% in Scotland and 11.5% in Wales, the difference resulting from [[Devolution in the United Kingdom|devolved government in those nations]].<ref name=Territorial/>
In 2018 [[Northamptonshire County Council]] become insolvent and proposed reducing services to the minimum required by law. Austerity measures were blamed for the insolvency, as was the council's refusal to raise council tax despite the rising costs of providing social services. At the time the [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]] said that up to 15 other local authorities were also at risk of insolvency.<ref name=Reckless>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/aug/01/northamptonshire-council-forced-pay-price-reckless-half-decade|title=Northamptonshire forced to pay the price of a reckless half-decade|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Patrick Butler|date=1 August 2018}}</ref> A survey of council leaders, chief executives and mayors conducted by the [[New Local Government Network]] indicated that more than 70% of respondents expected that they would be unable to provide non-statutory services beyond 2023 if funding remained as restricted as it had been since 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nlgn.org.uk/public/2018/18304/|title=Most local authorities will only deliver the bare minimum in five years time|date=9 August 2018|website=New Local Government Network}}</ref>
===Mental Health=== In 2016, figures analysed by the [[King's Fund]] think tank showed that "mental health trusts in England are still having their budgets cut, despite government assurances they would be funded on a par with physical healthcare". The analysis "suggests 40% of the 58 trusts saw budgets cut in 2015–16".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37657954|title=Mental health budgets 'still being cut despite pledge'|work=BBC News|date=14 October 2016|accessdate=21 May 2017}}</ref>
A 2016 report authored by the NatCen Social Research for [[UNISON]] shows that LGBT people have suffered from a lack of access to mental health services as a result of austerity.<ref name="pinkausteritymeasuressinclair">{{cite news|last1=Sinclair|first1=Sarah|title=Austerity measures are harming the LGBT community's mental health|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2016/11/25/austerity-measures-are-harming-the-lgbt-communitys-mental-health/|accessdate=26 November 2016|work=Pink News|date=25 November 2016}}</ref>
A 2015 report published by [[Psychologists for Social Change]] indicates that austerity has contributed significantly to the incidence and level of depression and other mental health conditions within the population.<ref>{{cite report|title=The Psychological Impact of Austerity: A Briefing Paper|url=http://www.psychchange.org/uploads/9/7/9/7/97971280/paa-briefing-paper.pdf|accessdate=17 March 2018|work=Psychologists for Social Change|author1=Laura McGrath |author2=Vanessa Griffin|author3=Ed Mundy}}</ref>
===Mortality=== In 2017, the [[Royal Society of Medicine]] said that government austerity decisions in health and social care were likely to have resulted in 30,000 deaths in England and Wales in 2015.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/feb/17/health-cuts-most-likely-cause-major-rise-mortality-study-claims|title=Health cuts most likely cause of major rise in mortality, study claims|author=Haroon Siddique|date=17 February 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/feb/18/people-are-dying-at-the-hands-of-austerity-says-jeremy-corbyn|title=Tony Blair's Brexit speech 'not helpful', says Jeremy Corbyn|author=Hannah Summers|date=18 February 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Research by [[University College London]] published in [[BMJ Open]] in 2017 compared the figures for health and social care funding during the 2000s with that during the period 2010–2014. It found that annual growth in health funding during the 2000s was 3.8%, but after 2010 this dropped to 0.41%. Annual growth in social care funding of 2.2% during the 2000s became an annual decrease of 1.57% after 2010. This coincided with mortality rates decreasing by 0.77% annually during the 2000s but rising by 0.87% annually after 2010.<ref>{{cite newspaper|date=15 November 2017|author=Alex Matthews-King|title=Landmark study links Tory austerity to 120,000 deaths|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/health/tory-austerity-deaths-study-report-people-die-social-care-government-policy-a8057306.html|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=16 November 2017}}</ref>
The rate of increase in [[life expectancy]] in England nearly halved between 2010 and 2017, according to research by epidemiology professor [[Michael Marmot]]. He commented that it was "entirely possible" that austerity was the cause<ref>{{cite news|title=Life expectancy rises 'grinding to halt' in England|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-40608256|work=BBC News|date=18 July 2017|author=Nick Triggle}}</ref> and said: "If we don't spend appropriately on social care, if we don't spend appropriately on health care, the quality of life will get worse for older people and maybe the length of life, too."<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Rise in life expectancy has stalled since 2010, research shows|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jul/18/rise-in-life-expectancy-has-stalled-since-2010-research-shows|author=Denis Campbell|date=18 July 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
A paper released by the [[The BMJ|British Medical Journal]] in November 2017 estimated that the government austerity programme caused around 120,000 excess deaths since 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/tory-health-cuts-economic-murder-11529388|title=Austerity linked to 120,000 deaths as policy is branded 'economic murder'|newspaper=Daily Mirror|author=Andrew Gregory|date=16 November 2017|accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/health/tory-austerity-deaths-study-report-people-die-social-care-government-policy-a8057306.html|title=Landmark study links Tory Austerity to 120,000 deaths|newspaper=The Independent|author=Alex Matthews-King|date=15 November 2017|accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref> By 2018 figures from the [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) were showing a fall in life expectancy for those in poorer socioeconomic groups and those living in deprived areas,<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Rise in life expectancy has stalled since 2010, research shows|url=https://theconversation.com/rapid-rise-in-mortality-in-england-and-wales-in-early-2018-an-investigation-is-needed-93311?|author=Danny Dorling|author2=Lucinda Hiam|date=15 March 2018|newspaper=The Conversation}}</ref> while average UK life expectancy had stopped improving. [[Public Health England]] was asked to carry out a review of life expectancy trends but government ministers said that the arguments put forward by some academics, that austerity had contributed to the change, could not be proved.<ref>{{cite news|title=Life expectancy progress in UK 'stops for first time'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-45638646|work=BBC News|author=Alex Therrien|date=25 September 2018}}</ref> ONS figures published in 2018 indicated that the slowdown in general life expectancy increase was one of the highest among a group of 20 of the world's leading economies.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-45096074|title=UK among worst for life expectancy rises|work=BBC News|date=7 August 2018}}</ref>
===Public sector pay=== There are approximately five million public sector workers in the UK. Between 2011 and 2013 there was a two-year pay freeze for all public sector workers<ref name=BBC28617>{{cite news|title=Public sector pay cap under review, No 10 suggests|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40423052|publisher=BBC News|date=28 June 2017}}</ref> earning an annual salary of £21,000 or more, which was expected to reduce public expenditure by £3.3 billion by 2014–15.<ref name=B&S>{{cite web|title=UK: Public sector pay|url=https://antiausteritylowresistancecapitalism.wordpress.com/con-dem-coalition-public-sector-pay/|work=Anti-austerity in Low-Resistance Models of Capitalism|first1=David|last1=Bailey|first2=Saori|last2=Shibata|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> In subsequent years a public sector pay cap resulted in annual public sector wage increases being effectively capped at 1% for 2013–2016,<ref name=BBC28617/> extended to 2020 in the 2015 budget.<ref name=B&S/> Advice was given to ministers by the civil service that the policy would result in a pay cut for many people in [[real terms]] and could increase [[child poverty]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-45994303|title=George Osborne kept pay cap despite child poverty warning|work=BBC|date=27 October 2018|author1=Chris Mason|author2=Katy Dillon}}</ref><ref name=guardian27/10/2018>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/27/george-osborne-ignored-poverty-warnings-on-public-sector-pay-cap|title=George Osborne ignored poverty warnings on 1% pay cap|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Rajeev Syal|date=27 October 2018}}</ref> By 2015 the number of people employed in the [[Civil Service (United Kingdom)|Civil Service]] had been reduced to the lowest level since [[World War II]] and public sector employees made up 17.2% of the total workforce, the smallest proportion since comparable records began in 1999.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Public sector austerity drive gathers pace in Autumn Statement|date=25 November 2015|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a3262b9e-9397-11e5-b190-291e94b77c8f?mhq5j=e1|author=Sarah O’Connor|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> During the 2017 general election the Conservative Party proposed retaining the cap until 2020, potentially reducing public sector expenditure by £5bn. A Labour Party amendment to the 2017 [[Speech from the throne|Queen's Speech]] proposing the removal of the cap was defeated.<ref name=BBC28617/> A 2017 report commissioned by the [[Office of Manpower Economics]] indicated that between 2005 and 2015 median hourly earnings fell by 3% in real terms for public sector workers whose salaries are set on the advice of pay review bodies<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/jul/03/damning-government-report-shows-scale-of-public-sector-pay-cuts|title=Damning government report shows depth of public sector pay cuts|newspaper=The Guardian|author1=Rowena Mason|author2=Anushka Asthana|date=3 July 2017}}</ref> (around 45% of public sector staff).<ref>{{cite web|title=About us|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/office-of-manpower-economics/about|publisher=Office of Manpower Economics|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, the [[Scottish Government]] announced that it intended to end the public sector pay cap in Scotland from 2018,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-41147003|title=Sturgeon says Scotland will end public sector pay cap|work=BBC News|date=5 September 2017}}</ref> and shortly afterwards the UK government announced the ending of the cap in England and Wales.<ref>{{cite news|title=Public sector pay cap to be lifted|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41241295|date=12 September 2017|work=BBC News}}</ref> By autumn 2017 public sector pay had fallen behind private sector pay for comparable work.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2017/oct/21/austerity-public-sector-pay-private|title=Austerity puts public workers' wages below private sector|newspaper=The Observer|date=21 October 2017|author=Jamie Doward}}</ref>
===Social security=== Working-age social security payments such as [[Universal Credit]], [[Child benefits in the United Kingdom|Child Benefit]], [[Child Tax Credit]] and [[Working Tax Credit]], [[Housing Benefit]] and [[Jobseeker's Allowance]] have had their rate of increase reduced by austerity.<ref name=£210>{{cite newspaper|title=Poorest families to lose out on £210 a year owing to benefits cap|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/13/poorest-families-to-lose-out-on-210-a-year-owing-to-benefits-cap|newspaper=The Guardian|author1=Heather Stewart|author2=Richard Partington|date=13 October 2018}}</ref> From 2013 onwards, these payments were limited to a maximum annual increase of 1% instead of being increased annually according to the rate of inflation. The policy of suspending the social security payments of unemployed claimants who were judged not to be adequately seeking work was continued, and the frequency and severity of the sanctions was increased.<ref>{{cite book|title=The British Coalition Government, 2010-2015: A Marriage of Inconvenience|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=o8YyDQAAQBAJ|first1=Peter|last1=Dorey|first2=Mark|last2=Garnett|year=2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781137023773|page=150–151}}</ref> From 2016 a four-year freeze on all working-age social security payments was introduced. It was anticipated that it would affect 11 million UK families and reduce expenditure by £9 billion, a figure later increased to £13 billion.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Spending freeze to cut extra £4bn from benefits as raft of new benefit cuts kick in|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/benefit-freeze-cuts-austerity-measures-welfare-state-inflation-a7661196.html|date=1 April 2017|author=Ashley Cowburn|newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> The [[Welfare Reform and Work Act 2016]] abolished the Work-Related Activity Component of [[Employment and Support Allowance]] for new claimants from April 2017. This reduced the weekly social security payments for the disabled people affected by £29.05 a week (at 2017/18 rates). The reduction in government expenditure was initially forecast to be £640 million per annum by 2020/21, though this was later revised to £450 million.<ref>{{cite report|title=Abolition of the ESA Work-Related Activity Component|url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-7649|date=7 March 2017|publisher=House of Commons Library (Briefing paper)}}</ref>
Analysis in 2018 by the [[Resolution Foundation]] indicated that by April 2019 the freeze in social security payments would have resulted in more than 10 million households experiencing a loss of income in [[real terms]], with the lack of an inflation-related increase in 2019 resulting in the average low-income couple with children losing an additional £210 per year. The analysis also said that the cumulative effect of these social security limitations had been to reduce the value of working-age benefits by more than 6% in real terms. Child Benefit had become worth less than it was in 1999 in real terms, and for a second child it was worth 14% less than when it was introduced in 1979.<ref name=£210/>
===State Pension=== The value of the [[State Pension (United Kingdom)|State Pension]] has not been subject to austerity measures, being increased each year since 2011 by a minimum of 2.5% per annum.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Pensions triple lock: what you need to know|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2017/apr/27/pensions-triple-lock-questions-answered|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Phillip Inman|date=27 April 2017}}</ref> However, some people have been adversely affected financially in their 60s by the rise in the age at which the State Pension is first paid. The decision to equalise the State Pension ages of men and women was made by the government in 1995. From 2010 the women's State Pension age was steadily raised from 60 with the aim of matching that of men at 65 by 2018. An additional increase to 66 for both sexes is intended to be implemented by 2020. Research by the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] (IFS) in 2017 found that the household incomes of over one million women aged between 60 and 62 had become £32 a week lower on average, and that poverty rates among that group had risen. The IFS also calculated that the reduction in state expenditure combined with the additional tax income from women continuing to work in their 60s resulted in a net increase in state revenue of £5.1 billion per year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Older women poorer after pension age change, says IFS|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-40791216|date=2 August 2017|work=BBC News}}</ref>
A rise in the State Pension age to 67 for both sexes in 2036 had been proposed by [[Gordon Brown]] in the 2000s, followed by a rise to 68 in 2046.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Pension age to rise within 7 years, say Conservatives|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/6263469/Pension-age-to-rise-within-7-years-say-Conservatives.html|newspaper=Telegraph|author1=Andrew Porter|author2=Robert Winnett|date=6 Oct 2009}}</ref> By 2014 the date set for the rise to 67 had been brought forward to 2026<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Age 40? No access to pension until 58|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/10982177/Age-40-No-access-to-pension-until-58.html|newspaper=Telegraph|author=Andrew Oxlade|date=22 Jul 2014}}</ref> and in 2018 the rise to 68 was brought forward to 2037. This last change alone resulted in an anticipated reduction in DWP expenditure of £74bn by 2046–47.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=State pension age: Millions of people will have to work an extra year before retiring at 68|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/state-pension-age-workers-people-extra-year-68-increase-retirement-age-david-gauke-a7849091.html|newspaper=Independent|author=Tom Batchelor|date=19 July 2017}}</ref>
==Northern Ireland== Reductions in public expenditure in Northern Ireland have often been described as not as harsh as those for the UK as a whole. This is primarily due to the fact that the UK government has not been able to exert direct control over welfare expenditure in Northern Ireland, because welfare policy is a devolved matter for the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]].<ref name=Nevin/> On a number of occasions the Assembly has not agreed to cuts in public spending, effectively refusing to make them, despite pressure from the UK government.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Northern Ireland braces for austerity|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a40aa234-c0f6-11e4-88ca-00144feab7de?mhq5j=e1|date=2 March 2015|author=Vincent Boland|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> However, the UK government has sought to recoup the expected savings through a fine on Northern Ireland's block grant, which is calculated according to the [[Barnett formula]], and which fell by 8% in real terms between 2010 and 2015.<ref name=Nevin/> Research by [[Oxfam]] Ireland which was published in 2014 indicated said that austerity measures were affecting Northern Ireland disproportionately due to its being one of the UK's most disadvantaged regions with a high dependence on public spending.<ref>{{cite news|title=Austerity creating 'more unequal NI society'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-25737952|date=15 January 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> In 2017 the [[Conservative–DUP agreement]] resulted in an additional £1 billion of public sector funding for Northern Ireland over two years, with the money focused on the health, infrastructure and education budgets.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40403434|title=Conservatives agree pact with DUP to support May government|date=26 June 2017|work=BBC News}}</ref>
==Reaction== During the early years of the austerity programme, many economists argued that the financial changes of the austerity programme should not be undertaken as extensively and as quickly as was done. Osborne, however, argued that without the implementation of the programme in the way that it was another financial crisis was likely.<ref name=Chu/>
The rationale behind the need for achieving a balanced budget in the financial climate following the Great Recession has been questioned by some [[Keynesian economics|Keynesian economists]]. [[Andrew Gamble]] writing in ''[[Parliamentary Affairs]]'' in 2015 commented:<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Economy|date=3 September 2015|last=Gamble|first=Andrew|doi=10.1093/pa/gsv033|url=https://academic.oup.com/pa/article/68/suppl_1/154/1403373/The-Economy|publisher=Oxford University Press and Hansard Society|journal=Parliamentary Affairs|volume=68|pages=154-167}}</ref> {{quote|Most macroeconomists now agree that the austerity programme pursued by the Coalition Government in its first two years was both too severe and unnecessary and set back the economic recovery which was underway in the first half of 2010. The Office of Budget Responsibility confirmed that the austerity programme reduced GDP, while the Oxford economist Simon Wren-Lewis has calculated that the Coalition Government's austerity programme cost the average household £4000 over the lifetime of the Parliament and severely damaged those public services which were not ring-fenced.}} [[Ha-Joon Chang]], writing in 2017, observed that "in today’s UK economy, whose underlying stagnation has been masked only by the release of excess liquidity on an oceanic scale, some deficit spending may be good – necessary, even".<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=The myths about money that British voters should reject|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/01/myths-money-british-voters-economy-britain-welfare|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Ha-Joon Chang|date=1 June 2017}}</ref><br><br>
Some criticism has been based allegations of [[economic opportunism]], with the government said to have made politically popular cuts rather than those necessary to achieve its long-term aims. Paul Mac Flynn wrote for the Nevin Economic Research Institute in 2015 that:<ref name=Nevin/>{{quote|Instead of focussing on the long-term structural causes of increases in public expenditure, the current government have adopted glib and uninformed targets for reductions in overall expenditure. Rather than tackling a housing crisis or low pay they have introduced measures like the benefit cap and the bedroom tax.}} Ben Chu, economics editor of ''[[The Independent]]'' newspaper, commented that: "Austerity, as practiced by Osborne, was essentially a political choice rather than an economic necessity, and the human costs have been huge".<ref name=Chu/>
Economists [[Alberto Alesina]], Carlo A. Favero and [[Francesco Giavazzi]], writing in ''[[Finance & Development]]'' in 2018, argued that deficit reduction policies based on spending cuts typically have almost no effect on output, and hence form a better route to achieving a reduction in the [[debt-to-GDP ratio]] than raising taxes. The authors commented that the UK government austerity programme had resulted in growth that was higher than the European average and that the UK's economic performance had been much stronger than the [[International Monetary Fund]] had predicted.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Climbing Out of Debt|first1=Alberto|last1=Alesina|first2=Carlo A.|last2=Favero|first3=Francesco|last3=Giavazzi|journal=Finance & Development|publisher=International Monetary Fund|date=March 2018|volume=55|issue=1|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2018/03/alesina.htm}}</ref>
The United Nations carried out an investigation in 2018 led by [[Philip Alston]], the [[United Nations special rapporteur]] on extreme poverty and human rights, into the effect of austerity policies in the UK.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/jun/28/united-nations-tory-record-poverty-human-rights|title=UN to investigate Tory record on poverty and human rights|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Robert Booth|date=28 June 2018}}</ref> Alston concluded that the austerity programme had breached UN human rights agreements relating to women, children, disabled people and economic and social rights.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=UK austerity has inflicted 'great misery' on citizens, UN says|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/nov/16/uk-austerity-has-inflicted-great-misery-on-citizens-un-says|newspaper=The Guardian|author1=Robert Booth|author2=Patrick Butler|date=16 November 2018}}</ref>
===Ring-fenced departments=== Peter Dominiczak (political editor at ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'') wrote that because spending on the NHS and foreign aid is ring-fenced, "other [[Whitehall]] departments will face savage cuts to their budgets".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/georgeosborne/11752132/George-Osborne-to-demand-20billion-of-Whitehall-cuts.html |title=George Osborne to demand £20billion of Whitehall cuts|author=Peter Dominiczak|date=21 July 2015}}</ref> However, some (such as Dr Louise Marshall in ''[[The Guardian]]'') have questioned whether the [[National Health Service]] (NHS) really is exempt from austerity measures.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marshall|first1=Dr Louise|title=Should we start preparing for a decade of austerity in the NHS?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2012/dec/03/preparing-decade-austerity-nhs|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=3 December 2012}}</ref>
==Public opinion==
A [[YouGov]] poll in 2015 found that whilst 58% of those surveyed viewed austerity as "necessary", and 48% judged it to be good for economy (compared to 34% who thought it bad for the economy), 50% thought the programme was being carried out "unfairly".<ref name=":0">{{cite web|first=Liam|last=Stanley|url=http://speri.dept.shef.ac.uk/2015/07/09/public-opinion-graphs-austerity/|title=What six public opinion graphs tell us about austerity|publisher=Sheffield Political Economy Research Institute|access-date=16 June 2018|date=9 July 2015|}}</ref>
The 2017 [[British Social Attitudes Survey]] found that 48% of those surveyed during the previous year wanted higher taxes to pay for more public spending, the first time since 2008 that more people wanted an increase in taxation and spending than opposed it, and the highest proportion to support such measures since 2004.<ref>{{cite news|title=British Attitudes Survey: More Britons 'back higher taxes'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40408576|work=BBC News|date=26 June 2017}}</ref>
An April 2018 opinion poll by [[Number Cruncher Politics]] in the [[Financial Times]] found that 66% of British adults, including majorities of all major parties' supporters, thought austerity had "gone too far".<ref>{{cite news|title=Poll shows even Tory voters feel austerity has gone too far|url=https://www.ft.com/content/c8d95118-4a42-11e8-8c77-ff51caedcde6|work=Financial Times|date=2 May 2018}}</ref> A poll by [[Survation]] for the [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] trade union published in spring 2018 found that 62% of respondents wanted the 2018 spring budget to increase spending on public services in real terms, while 48% of those who had voted for the Conservative Party at the 2017 general election thought that austerity had been excessive.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/mar/13/philip-hammond-austerity-chancellor-spring-statement|title=Philip Hammond is trying to hide the pain of austerity. Don’t fall for it|author=Faiza Shaheen|date=13 March 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
==Effects on general elections== The [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]] was contested by a [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] which had both committed themselves to austerity policies. Labour's then-[[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Alistair Darling]] predicted that "two parliaments of pain" would be necessary to address the UK's budget deficit. The [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] said that Labour's plans implied a cumulative decline of 11.9% in public spending over four years. This would reduce public expenditure by a total of £46 billion in inflation-adjusted terms, taking it from over 27% of the economy to below 21%, back to its level in the late-1990s. The IFS also said that there appeared to be only a modest difference between the plans put forward by the two main political parties.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Alistair Darling: we will cut deeper than Margaret Thatcher|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/mar/25/alistair-darling-cut-deeper-margaret-thatcher|date=25 March 2010|first=Larry|last=Elliott|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Neither party won a majority at that year's general election, resulting in a hung parliament with the Conservative Party forming a coalition government with the [[centrist]] [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]].
At the end of the first full parliament under the austerity programme, the Labour Party and the Conservatives were deadlocked in the polls. At the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], the Conservative Party modified their commitment to austerity with a series of unfunded spending promises, including £8 billion of additional expenditure for the [[National Health Service|NHS]].<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Tories break with austerity and promise ‘good life’ to voters|url=https://www.ft.com/content/cd8de610-e2a8-11e4-ba33-00144feab7de?mhq5j=e1|date=14 April 2015|author=George Parker|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref> At the same time, the 2015 Conservative Party general election manifesto proposed making sufficient reductions in public spending and welfare to eliminate the budget deficit entirely by 2018–19 and run a small budget surplus by 2020. The Labour Party's manifesto proposed the less rigorous objective of reducing the budget deficit every year with the aim of seeing debt as a share of GDP falling by 2020 and achieving a budget surplus "as soon as possible". This would render the spending reductions proposed by the Conservatives unnecessary, according to some analyses.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Labour manifesto 2015: the key policies and what they mean for you|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/labour/11532277/manifesto-2015-summary.html|date=5 May 2015|author=Matthew Holehouse|newspaper=The Telegraph}}</ref> The Conservative Party won the general election with an overall majority for the first time in 23 years, which was unexpected by most polls as they had predicted another hung parliament.<ref name=Tapper>{{cite newspaper|title=Anti-austerity protesters take to UK streets after Tory election victory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/may/09/anti-austerity-protesters-take-to-uk-streets-after-tory-election-victory|newspaper=The Guardian|author=James Tapper|date=9 May 2015}}</ref> Political commentator [[Patrick Wintour]] argued that one of the reasons for Labour's loss was its lack of clarity on the cause of the budget deficit.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jun/03/undoing-of-ed-miliband-and-how-labour-lost-election|title=The undoing of Ed Miliband – and how Labour lost the election|last=Wintour|first=Patrick|date=3 June 2015|newspaper=the Guardian|access-date=16 June 2018}}</ref> Anti-austerity protests followed the election result,<ref name=Tapper/> but post-election polling for an independent review conducted by Campaign Company for Labour MP [[Jon Cruddas]] indicated that voters in England and Wales did not support an anti-austerity platform, concluding: "the Tories did not win despite austerity, but because of it".<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Anti-austerity unpopular with voters, finds inquiry into Labour's election loss|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/aug/04/anti-austerity-voters-poll-jeremy-corbyn-labour|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Patrick Wintour|date=4 August 2015}}</ref>
The [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]] was held almost three years earlier than scheduled under the [[Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011]] in an attempt to increase the Government's majority to facilitate the [[Brexit]] process. The Conservative Party manifesto pledged to eliminate the deficit by the "middle of the next decade",<ref>{{cite news|title=Reality check: How big is the UK's deficit and debt?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-39897498|work=BBC News|date=17 May 2017}}</ref> an aim which the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] (IFS) said would "likely require more spending cuts or tax rises even beyond the end of the next parliament". The Labour Party manifesto proposed increasing the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]]'s income by £49 billion per year as a result of taxation rises and increasing public expenditure "to its highest sustained level in more than 30 years". The IFS said that Labour's proposals "could be expected to raise ''at most'' £40 billion" and that Labour was planning to maintain a majority of the cuts to working-age benefits proposed by the Conservatives.<ref>{{cite newspaper|title=Tory plan to balance budget by mid-2020s 'could require tax rises'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/05/26/tory-plan-balance-budget-mid-2020s-could-require-tax-rises/|date=26 May 2017|author=Edward Malnick|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> As a result of the election, the Conservative Party lost their parliamentary majority, but remained in government as the largest single party in parliament. [[Gavin Barwell]], Theresa May's [[Downing Street Chief of Staff]], blamed anger over Brexit and austerity for the loss of seats.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40251997|title=Theresa May's chief of staff Gavin Barwell: Austerity and Brexit cost us|date=12 June 2017|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> The Labour opposition announced a plan to challenge further austerity measures and vote against them in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]. A Labour spokesman said: "We will be using the changed parliamentary arithmetic to drive home the fact that the Tory programme for five more years of austerity will not go on as before."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/09/theresa-may-hopes-to-remain-pm-as-voters-deliver-hung-parliament|title=Theresa May adopts contrite tone after Tory MPs vent anger over election|newspaper=The Guardian|author= Heather Stewart|date=10 June 2017}}</ref>
